Description: (3rd-1st m. BC) Also called Mis Ainak or Mis-e-Ainak, was a major Buddhist settlement 40 km southeast of Kabul, Afghanistan, located in a barren region of Logar Province. The site possesses a vast complex of Buddhist monasteries, homes, over 400 Buddha statues, stupas and market areas. Archaeologists are only beginning to find remnants of an older 5,000 year old Bronze Age site beneath the Buddhist level.

Description: (4th c. BC) A Roman city established on a plateau. It had a monumental gate, baths, industrial facilities, a sanctuary to Mithras dating back to the 4th century BC, and also a Christian chapel. On the slopes of the cliff one can see many houses and the remains of the original rampart of the castellum.

Description: (1st-7th c. AD) The ruins of a Roman city. The ruins are noteworthy for representing one of the best extant examples of the grid plan as used in Roman town planning. The original Roman grid plan is visible in the orthogonal design. At the west end of the decumanus rises a 12 metres high triumphal arch primarily made of sandstone, called the Arch of Trajan, and is of the Corinthian order with three arches. The other key buildings include: a theatre, four thermae, a library, and a basilica.

properties.description:
Description: (12th c. AD) The historic ensemble of Meritxell is comprised of two buildings: the old sanctuary and the new, both of them declared heritage of cultural interest. The pope Francis granted the sanctuary the title of Minor Basilica, in honour of its singular liturgical life, its religious work and its history and cultural activity. This recognition gives at Meritxell an incalculable religious value, the worship place most important in Andorra. The old sanctuary completely disappeared in a fire in 1972, after one of the gatherings held in the sanctuary. It was a 16th century building of Romanesque origin, where you could find the ancient image of the patron saint of Andorra, a 12th-century Romanesque carving that, because of the shoes she wore, was popularly called the Mother of God of the Clovers, and that it was also destroyed in the fire. The current image has been recreated as faithfully as possible and is in the new sanctuary of Meritxell.
Category:
Category (multi): Temple complex
Location: Andorra
Coordinates: 42.55478184324733, 1.5914246262752028
Source: https://ca.wikipedia.org/wiki/Bas%C3%ADlica_Santuari_de_Nostra_Senyora_de_Meritxell https://rutamariana.com/en/meritxell/
Images: https://upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/1/18/Exteriors_Santuari_Mare_de_D%C3%A9u_de_Meritxell.jpg

properties.description:
Description: (11th-12th c. AD) A church located in Canillo, Andorra. It is a heritage property registered in the Cultural Heritage of Andorra. It was built in the 11–12th century. Inside the building different artistic pieces are preserved, the main one being a large stucco image of Christ in Majesty, as well as a mural with frescoes depicting scenes from Calvary with Saint Longinus and Stephaton, accompanied by the half-hidden Sun and Moon, works from the 12th century. There is also a retable dating from the 16th century of exceptional quality. Influenced by the Italian and Germanic Renaissance style, it depicts scenes from the life and martyrdom of Saint John the apostle, author of the book of revelation and patron saint of the church, in particular his visions in Patmos.

Description: (8th-12th c. AD) Andorra' oldest church located in Santa Coloma, Andorra la Vella Parish, Andorra. The nave of the church was built in the 8th or 9th century, and the tower in the 12th century. In the church are visible remnants of murals made in the 12th century by the Master of Sant Coloma. Most of the murals were removed in 1933 and were in Berlin until 2007. These murals are now present in the Andorran Government Exhibition Hall.

properties.description:
Description: (12th c. AD) A Romanesque church from the Lombard period dedicated to St. Roman. Located in the Encamp parish of Andorra, Saint Roman of Les Bons is one of the oldest churches in the country. This ancient building has been beautifully preserved over the centuries and continues to stand strong. Built-in the 12th century, it is a striking example of Romanesque architecture. The church is best known for its soaring bell tower, which dominates the surrounding area. Inside, visitors will find several interesting features, such as the ornate marble altar and beautiful stained glass windows.

The bell tower was added during the second half of the 11th century and is the highest Lombard Romanesque bell tower in the country. A wrought iron cross atop a pumice pedestal lies atop the roof. The church of Santa Eulàlia has the oldest porch in the Principality, as well as one of the few conjuratories still standing in the country.

properties.description:
Description: (12th c. AD) Sant Julià i Sant Germà is the most important church in the parish of Sant Julià de Lòria and continues its ecclesiastical activity on a daily basis. Of Romanesque origin, the church was restored and reformed in the modern age. It still retains its square and solid three-storey Lombard bell tower, made using a well-ordered rigging of regular stone blocks, with arches and lesenes. Inside, in addition to a carving of the Holy Christ, we find the baroque altarpieces of Sant Julià, of the Immaculate Conception (18th century) and of Sant Germà, as well as two 12th-century carvings of the Virgin of Canòlic and of the Virgin of Los Remedios.

properties.description:
Description: A church located next to the gorge of La Grella and under the tunnels of the same name, under the town of Sispony and within the parish of La Massana. This chapel is attached to the stone where the Valira del Nord river passes deeply gorged between high stone walls and dense riverside vegetation on the old road that joined the parishes of La Massana and Escaldes-Engordany. The works for the opening of the road tunnels damaged it to the point of destroying it for the most part, but it was later completely restored. This chapel is dedicated to Sant Antoni Abat, patron saint of porters, which they invoked before going through a congested passageway. A hundred metres below is the Romanesque bridge of Sant Antoni de la Grella.

properties.description:
Description: (11th-19th c. AD) A Romanesque church in the center of Erts in the Andorran parish of La Massana. It is located when you reach the village of Erts, near where the new church is, a simple 18th century building. The ruins of an old church are located near the houses of the village, where there is a path that takes you to the orchards. There we will find an electricity transformer, which is in fact located partly on top of what used to be the floor of the old chapel. In terms of construction, it is a very small church made up of a single, rectangular volume. The facade consists of a wooden door and two quadrangular windows on each side. The entrance has a small porch that protects it. Just above we see a bell tower of disproportionate sizes compared to the church with two semicircular arched openings. The north wall of the old church is currently preserved. Some remains of mural paintings have been preserved on this wall, although their state of preservation does not allow us to make an exact dating. The part of the apse has been preserved as a retaining wall for the path.

Description: (9th c. AD) A Romanesque church in the parish of Andorra la Vella, in the village of Santa Coloma, Andorra. This primitive Church formed part of the fortified visigothic complex of Enclar. Sant Vicenç is rectangular in shape with a square apse. It has a circular bell tower against the southern wall of the nave, crowned with a floor of windows and a second floor of seven small extended arched windows. Its construction most likely took place in the ninth century, as its type is similar to the usual types of Catalan and Languedoc architecture from the 10th and earlier centuries.

properties.description:
Description: (1701 AD) A church located in Bixessarri, Sant Julià de Lòria Parish, Andorra. It has a rectangular plan without an apse and covered with a two sided roof. It has a bell tower in the wall and the porch and the nave is whitewashed. It is built with medium-sized and small stones set out in rows. The roof of the nave is in open wood beams.The door shows the lintel, the columns, the band and the feet decorated with borders. The date of 1701 is engraved on the lintel. The wall bell tower with a single hole stands at the top of the west facade. The apse, on a higher level than the nave, is presided by an 18th-century baroque altarpiece dedicated to St Stephen. The nave with a stone floor preserves part of the furniture and the wooden choir of baroque times (18th and 19th centuries)

properties.description:
Description: An ancient spring site. In Pyrenean Catalan, “cóm” is a feeding trough and, in fact, this spring was often used by the horses of the village and muleteers who passed by such as the ‘arrieros’. The road where the spring is located, carrer Doctor Palau, was formerly called the Carrer dels Cavallers [Knight’s street]. It was so called because this street was the main road from Seu d'Urgell to Andorra la Vella, and passed through the village and was therefore a compulsory stopping place for all ‘arrieros’ or muleteers coming through with their animals, normally mules.

Description: (7th-10th c. AD) A medieval Armenian cathedral. Now lying in ruins, Zvartnots was noted for its circular exterior structure, unique in medieval Armenian architecture, and a set of interior piers that upheld a multifloor structure crowned with a dome. Description: (10th c. AD) A Cambodian temple dedicated to the Hindu god Shiva. Banteay Srei is built largely of red sandstone, a medium that lends itself to the elaborate decorative wall carvings which are still observable today. The buildings themselves are miniature in scale, unusually so when measured by the standards of Angkorian construction. These factors have made the temple extremely popular with tourists, and have led to its being widely praised as a "precious gem", or the "jewel of Khmer art".

properties.description:
Description: (11th-12th c. AD) An Angkorian-era archaeological site on the southwest slopes of the Kulen Hills to the northeast of Angkor. The site consists of a series of stone rock relief carvings in sandstone formations of the river bed and banks. It is commonly known as the "Valley of a 1000 Lingas" or "The River of a Thousand Lingas". The motifs for stone carvings are mainly myriads of lingams (phallic symbol of Hindu god Shiva), depicted as neatly arranged bumps that cover the surface of a sandstone bed rock, and lingam-yoni designs. There are also various Hindu mythological motifs, including depictions of the gods Shiva, Vishnu, Brahma, Lakshmi, Rama, and Hanuman, as well as animals (cows and frogs).
Category:
Category (multi): Petroglyphs
Location: Cambodia

Description: (12th c. AD) An artificial island with a Buddhist temple on a circular island in Jayatataka Baray, which was associated with Preah Khan temple, built during the reign of King Jayavarman VII. Originally designed for medical purposes (the ancients believed that going into these pools would balance the elements in the bather, thus curing disease); it is one of the many hospitals that Jayavarman VII built. Some historians believe that Neak Pean represents Anavatapta,: a mythical lake in the Himalayas whose waters are thought to cure all illness.

Description: A volcanic crater formed of consolidated volcanic ash. It was a quarry for about 500 years and supplied the stone from which about 95% of the island's known moai were carved. The incomplete statues in the quarry are remarkable both for their number, for the inaccessibility of some that were high on the outside crater wall and for the size of the largest.

Location: Chile, Easter Island
Coordinates: -27.123010046970556, -109.28608954232887

properties.description:
Description: The largest ahu on Easter Island (Rapa Nui). Its moais were toppled during the island's civil wars, and in the twentieth century the ahu was swept inland by a tsunami. It has since been restored and has fifteen moai, including one that weighs eighty-six tonnes, the heaviest ever erected on the island. Ahu Tongariki is one kilometer from Rano Raraku and Poike in the Hotu-iti area of Rapa Nui National Park. All the moai here face sunset during the winter solstice.
Category:
Category (multi): Megalithic statues
Location: Chile, Easter Island

properties.description:
Description: The Ahu Nau Nau is located about 150 metres inland from the quiet shore of Anakena Beach. From there it dominates the perspective of this magical place that is considered the birthplace of the history and culture of Easter Island. It was here that, according to oral tradition, the high-ranking chiefs of the powerful Miru clan established their residence, and where the first king of the island, the Ariki Hotu Matu’a, landed with his people and established the first settlement that originated to the Rapa Nui culture.

Location: Chile, Easter Island

properties.description:
Description: Te Pito Kura is an archaeological complex located in front of the Bay of La Pérouse, about two kilometers southeast of Ovahe beach. In this ceremonial center is the Ahu or Paro, whose only moai named Paro, remains in the same position it was when it was demolished almost two centuries ago. The Paro Moai represents a milestone from the period when the statues were built, as it is the largest moai statue transported from the Rano Raraku volcano quarry and erected successfully on an ahu or platform. Its dimensions are spectacular: its ears measure 2 meters, its height reaches 10 meters and it is estimated that its weight must exceed 80 tons.
Category: Megalithic statues
Category (multi): Megalithic statues
Location: Chile, Easter Island
Coordinates: -27.08530205224297, -109.30088245602465
Source: https://imaginarapanui.com/en/easter-island-sightseeing/easter-island-archaeology/ahu-te-pito-kura/

properties.description:
Description: Next to the ahu, a few meters away, is a large ovoid shaped stone 80 centimeters in diameter. The expression Te Pito Kura means “navel of light” and some people relate the name of the place with the special qualities of this rock and with one of the names with which it is known to Easter Island, Te Pito O Te Henua which means “navel of the world”. This singular stone was formerly known as Tita’a hanga ‘o te henua, and according to legend, was brought by Hotu Matu’a, the founding king of the Rapanui people, in his boat from Hiva, his native land. It is said that this rock, almost spherical and smooth, concentrates a magnetic and supernatural energy called mana.
Category: Magnetic anomaly
Category (multi): Magnetic anomaly
Location: Chile, Easter Island
Coordinates: -27.085202543505925, -109.30202888982558
Source: https://imaginarapanui.com/en/easter-island-sightseeing/easter-island-archaeology/ahu-te-pito-kura/

properties.description:
Description: Puna Pau is a small extinct volcano, located about 7 km northeast of Hanga Roa, whose name refers to a source or well of water that should have existed in its surroundings. This crater is part of a set of parasitic cones that emerged during the eruptions of Ma’unga Terevaka, the youngest and highest volcano on Easter Island. Inside the Puna Pau crater there is a quarry of red scoria that was once an important source of raw material for the islanders. The red scoria or hani hani, as it is known in the Rapanui language, is a type of volcanic ash of great porosity and scarce hardness, which shows a reddish color due to the iron oxide present in its composition.
Category: Megalithic stones
Category (multi): Megalithic stones
Location: Chile, Easter Island
Coordinates: -27.146434555466964, -109.40201242143034
Source: https://imaginarapanui.com/en/easter-island-sightseeing/easter-island-volcanoes/puna-pau/

properties.description:
Description: Ahu Akivi is located on the southwest flank of the Maunga Terevaka volcano, the highest point on the island, 2.6 km inland from the central west coast, where Ana Kakenga, the cave of the two windows, is located. This location is already significant, since most of the ceremonial platforms are on the coastal edge of the island. Of the few ahu built in the interior of the island (about thirty), Ahu Akivi is the most important and elaborate platform of all of them. According to excavations and studies carried out, it is thought that the first phase of construction of the ahu began towards the end of the 15th century. First, a rectangular platform was erected on a level surface, from which a 25-meter ramp to the central plaza started. On the back a crematorium used in the cremation ceremonies was located.
Category: Megalithic statues
Category (multi): Megalithic statues
Location: Chile, Easter Island
Coordinates: -27.114327221940712, -109.39286467595336
Source: https://imaginarapanui.com/en/easter-island-sightseeing/easter-island-archaeology/ahu-akivi/

Description: (493-1127 AD) Longmen Caves are some of the finest examples of Chinese Buddhist art. Housing tens of thousands of statues of Shakyamuni Buddha and his disciples. The images, many once painted, were carved as outside rock reliefs and inside artificial caves excavated from the limestone cliffs. The area also contains nearly 2,500 stelae and inscriptions. The grottoes were excavated and carved with Buddhist subjects in four distinct phases.

Description: (108 BC-13th c. AD) A ruined city. It was the capital of the Tocharian Kingdom of Jushi. It is a natural fortress located atop a steep cliff on a leaf-shaped plateau between two deep river valleys. The ruins were visited by the archaeologist and explorer Aurel Stein, who described "a maze of ruined dwellings and shrines carved out for the most part from the loess soil". It was finally abandoned after its destruction during an invasion by the Mongols led by Genghis Khan.

Category (multi): Temple complex

Description: (713-803 AD) A 71 metre tall stone statue of a seated Buddah, built during the Tang dynasty. It is carved out of a cliff face of Cretaceous red bed sandstones that lies at the confluence of the Min River and Dadu River in the southern part of Sichuan province in China. The stone sculpture faces Mount Emei, with the rivers flowing below its feet. It is the largest and tallest stone Buddha statue in the world, and it is by far the tallest pre-modern statue in the world.

properties.description:
Description: (2nd c. AD) The Twin Gates were built on the remains of older Roman gates, and their main role was to serve as an entrance to the ancient theater. The construction is simple, with two arch passes decorated with three half-pillars, which have composite capitals on top. The construction is connected with relief corona which decorates the gates. Above the arches there is a slot for the portcullis. There are visible signs of damage along the whole construction, because the gates were buried to enforce the defensive structure of the town. Today they practically don’t lead anywhere, but belong to the building of Archeological museum and a park with tall cedars.
Category:
Category (multi): Megalithic stones, Megalithic structures
Location: Croatia
Coordinates: 44.871061362908875, 13.848132917840898
Source: https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Porta_Gemina

properties.description:
Description: (47-44 BC) The Gate of Hercules in Pula stands between two medieval towers. It is built of uncarved stone blocks at the top of which is a carving of the head of Hercules with visible beard, curly hair and a club, in poor condition. Unfortunately, a historically very important inscription of two Roman officials, Lucius Calpurnius Piso and Gaius Cassius Longinus standing close to the club has been damaged. The Gate of Hercules was not richly decorated, as they did not differ from the exterior coat of the Pula city walls.
Category:
Category (multi): Megalithic stones, Megalithic structures
Location: Croatia
Coordinates: 44.870338586242454, 13.848325802498584

properties.description:
Description: (27 BC-14 AD) A well-preserved Roman temple dedicated to Augustus. It was built on a podium with a tetrastyle prostyle porch of Corinthian columns. The temple was part of a triad consisting of three temples. The Temple of Augustus stood at the left side of the central temple, and the similar temple of the goddess Diana stood on the other side of the main temple. Although the larger central temple has not survived, the whole back side of the Temple of Diana is still clearly visible due to its incorporation into the Communal Palace, built in 1296.
Category:
Category (multi): Temple complex
Location: Croatia
Coordinates: 44.87025975398996, 13.84219882948512

Description: (12th-16th c. AD) The necropolis Velika and Mala Crljivica. South of Velika Crljivica, the eastern part of the site, lays a karst sinkhole with seven wells. 102 stećci of all basic types have been preserved: slabs, chests and gabled roof tombstones. Decorative motifs are the following: crosses of all forms, anthropomorphic lilies, hunting scenes, scenes of people dancing kolo, jousting scenes, various vegetal motifs, crescents, stars and half-spheres, and 52 stećci bear decorations. Two stećci have partially preserved inscriptions in Cyrillic script mentioning the spouses Jerko and Vladna Kustražić.
Category:

Description: (600-475 BC) A large archaeological site. The site has unearthed the temple of Aphrodite, two majestic royal tombs, as well as several smaller ones. The latter are now exhibited in the Cyprus Archaeological Museum in Lefkosia (Nicosia).

Description: Qasr el-Sagha rests on a level platform on the side of an escarpment. The plan of the temple suggests the structure was built no later than the Middle Kingdom, but its architecture was interpreted by early explorers as being in the style of the Old Kingdom structures. The temple was constructed of limestone blocks of different sizes, which fit regularly together without the use of mortar and with oblique corner joints. The temple was never completed.

properties.description:
Description: The Philae temple complex is an island-based temple complex in the reservoir of the Aswan Low Dam, downstream of the Aswan Dam and Lake Nasser, Egypt. The temple complex was dismantled and moved from Philae Island to nearby Agilkia Island protecting this and other complexes before the 1970 completion of the Aswan High Dam. Monuments of various eras, extending from the Pharaohs to the Caesars, occupy nearly their whole area. The most ancient was a temple for Isis, built in the reign of Nectanebo I during 380-362 BC. For the most part, the other ruins date from the Ptolemaic Kingdom, more especially with the reigns of Ptolemy II Philadelphus, Ptolemy V Epiphanes, and Ptolemy VI Philometor (282-145 BC), with many traces of Roman work in Philae dedicated to Ammon-Osiris.
Category:
Category (multi): Temple complex
Location: Egypt
Coordinates: 24.025558787056717, 32.88410786487819
Source:

properties.description:
Description: The unfinished obelisk is the largest known ancient obelisk and is located in the stone quarries of Aswan, Egypt. The obelisk and wider quarry were inscribed on the UNESCO World Heritage List in 1979 along with other examples of Upper Egyptian architecture.
Its creation was ordered by Hatshepsut (1508–1458 BC) and, if finished, it would have measured around 41.75 metres (137.0 ft and would have weighed nearly 1,090 tonnes (1,200 short tons), a weight equal to about 200 African elephants.
The obelisk's creators began to carve it directly out of bedrock, but cracks appeared in the granite and the project was abandoned. The bottom side of the obelisk is still attached to the bedrock.
The unfinished obelisk offers unusual insights into ancient Egyptian stone-working techniques, with mysterious scoop marks from workers' tools still clearly visible as well as ochre-coloured lines marking where they were working.
Category:
Category (multi): Megalithic stones
Location: Egypt
Coordinates: 24.076910492622854, 32.895451022990954
Source: https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Unfinished_obelisk

properties.description:
Description: The Temple of Edfu is located on the west bank of the Nile in Edfu, Upper Egypt.  It is one of the best preserved shrines in Egypt. The temple was built in the Ptolemaic Kingdom between 237 and 57 BC. The inscriptions on its walls provide important information on language, myth and religion during the Hellenistic period in Egypt. In particular, the Temple's inscribed building texts provide details both of its construction, and also preserve information about the mythical interpretation of this and all other temples as the Island of Creation. There are also important scenes and inscriptions of the Sacred Drama which related the age-old conflict between Horus and Seth.

Description: The Temple of Dakka was originally built by a Meroitic or Nubian King in honour of Thoth at around 220 BC. It was originally known to the Ancient Egyptians as Pselqet, while the Greeks called it Pselchis. The temple is today located at Wadi El Seboua after being relocated to save it from the waters of Lake Nasser. During the years of Roman rule, the Temple was converted into a fortress and enclosed by a surrounding wall that had its main entrance on the banks of the Nile. The relocation of the temple did not include any part of this wall.

Description: The Temple of Amada, the oldest Egyptian temple in Nubia, was first constructed by Pharaoh Thutmose III of the 18th dynasty and dedicated to Amun and Re-Horakhty. The decoration program was continued by his successors Amenhotep II and Thutmose IV who decided to place a roof over its forecourt and transform it into a pillared or hypostyle hall. The temple's interior features some of the most finely cut reliefs with bright and vibrant colours. The temple was relocated in the 1960s to avoid flooding by the building of the Aswan High Dam.

Category (multi): Temple complex
Location: Egypt

properties.description:
Description: (1279-1213 BC) The Temple of Hathor at Abu Simbel was built by Ramesses II to honour both Hathor as the goddess of love/music and his wife Nefertari as a deified queen. The facade, resembling a pylon, has six standing colossal (over 10 meters high) statues. The plan of the Small Temple is a simplified version of that of the Great Temple. Remarkably, this is one of very few instances in Egyptian art where the statues of the king and his consort have equal size. The temple was one of those relocated in the 1960s to avoid flooding by the building of the Aswan High Dam.
Category:
Category (multi): Temple complex, Megalithic statues
Location: Egypt
Coordinates: 22.337811256095087, 31.627692046126516

properties.description:
Description: Abu Simbel is a historic site comprising two massive rock-cut temples in the village of Abu Simbel, near the border with Sudan. It is situated on the western bank of Lake Nasser. The twin temples were originally carved out of the mountainside in the 13th century BC, during the 19th Dynasty reign of the Pharaoh Ramesses II. They serve as a lasting monument to the king Ramesses II. His wife Nefertari and children can be seen in smaller figures by his feet, considered to be of lesser importance and were not given the same position of scale. This commemorates his victory at the Battle of Kadesh. Their huge external rock relief figures have become iconic.The temple was one of those relocated in the 1960s to avoid flooding by the building of the Aswan High Dam.
Category:
Category (multi): Temple complex, Megalithic statues
Location: Egypt
Coordinates: 22.337350985256432, 31.62651246756592

Description: Trajan's Kiosk, also known as Pharaoh's Bed, is a hypaethral temple currently located on Agilkia Island in southern Egypt. The unfinished monument is attributed to Trajan, Roman emperor from 98 to 117 AD, due to his depiction as pharaoh seen on some of the interior reliefs. The temple was originally built on the island of Philae, near the lower Aswan Dam but it was relocated to Agilika Island in the 1960s to save it from the rising waters of the Nile that followed the construction of the Aswan High Dam.

properties.description:
Description: The step tomb of Khentkaus I is a Fourth Dynasty two-stepped tomb built for the Queen Mother Khentkaus I in Giza. The tomb, built in two phases coinciding with its two steps, was originally known as the fourth pyramid of Giza. Her tomb was later enlarged with a large limestone structure built on top of the bedrock block. South-west of the tomb was a long boat pit, which housed the Night boat of Re. A companion day boat has not been found. A chapel was built into the tomb superstructure, with a large granite entrance bearing the queen's name and titles.
Category:
Category (multi): Necropolis/tombs complex, Pyramid complex
Location: Egypt
Coordinates: 29.973440234137964, 31.135357259617876

Description: Hatshepsut (c.1473–1458 BC), the queen who became Pharaoh, built a magnificent temple at Deir al-Bahari, on the west back of Luxor. It lies directly across the Nile from Karnak Temple, the main sanctuary of the god Amun. Hatshepsut’s temple, Djeser-djeseru “the Holy of Holies” was designed by the chief steward of Amun, Senenmut. The temple consists of three levels each of which has a colonnade at its far end. On the uppermost level, an open courtyard lies just beyond the portico. Mummiform statues of Hatshepsut as Osiris, the god of the dead, lean against its pillars.
Category: Megalithic structures
Category (multi): Megalithic structures, Temple complex

properties.description:
Description: (6th c. AD) Set on a small hill are two tombs that local tradition attributes to King Kaleb and his son, King Gebre Meskel. Although the twin tombs’ architecture resembles the Tomb of the False Door, they show more sophistication, using irregular-shaped, self-locking stones that don’t require iron clamps. The Gebre Meskel tomb is the most refined. The tomb consists of one chamber and five rooms, with one boasting a carved portal leading into it. Inside that room are three sarcophagi. King Kaleb’s tomb is accessed via a long straight stairway. Inside, the stones are larger, more angular and less precisely joined. Above ground, a raised courtyard combines the two tombs. Some scholars have suggested that two parallel churches with a basilica plan lay here, probably postdating the tombs.
Category:
Category (multi): Necropolis/tombs complex
Location: Ethiopia
Coordinates: 14.14260755674387, 38.72994692153899
Source:
Images:

Description: (4th c. BC-6th c. AD) "Tomb of the False Door". It lies in the western extremity of the Northern Stelae Field. More complex in structure, its stone blocks are also larger and more finely dressed than those found in some other tombs. Comprising an antechamber and inner chamber, it's surrounded on three sides by a passage. Above the tomb, at ground level, a rectangular, probably flat-roofed building would once have stood. A damaged single stone sarcophagus can still be seen.

Description: (4th c. BC-13th c. AD) A town in the Amhara Region of Ethiopia. It is a tourist site known for its rock-cut monolithic churches. The whole of Lalibela is a large and important site for the antiquity, medieval, and post-medieval civilization of Ethiopia. Description: (1st c. BC) An ancient tower that belongs to the ancient rampart, one of the first architectural achievements of the Roman colony. The Tower of Mourgues was originally a large cylindrical tower six metres high, which reinforced this part of the Roman city. It was constructed with the load bearing masonry technique. It takes its name from the nuns (mourgues), from the monastery that Bishop Césaire founded nearby, at the beginning of the 6th century, and of which the nearby Saint-Blaise church remains.

Description: (4th-12th c. AD) A large Roman necropolis and medieval cemetry. It was one of the most famous necropoli of the ancient world. The Alyscamps was Arles' main burial ground for nearly 1,500 years. It was the final segment of the Aurelian Way leading up to the city gates and was used as a burial ground for well-off citizens, whose memorials ranged from simple sarcophagi to elaborate monuments. The Alyscamps continued to be used after the city was Christianised in the 4th century and most monuments are from that period. The better of the remaining sarcophagi are now on display in the Musée de l'Arles et de la Provence antiques.

Description: Also known as the Menhir of Bourg-Jardin is a menhir located in Avrillé, in the French department of Vendée, France. The menhir is 8.70 metres high, including 7 metres above ground, making it the highest menhir in Vendée and one of the largest south of the Loire. It is a monolithic granite block whose weight is estimated at around 85 ton. The traces of the notches which allowed the extraction of the block are still visible.

Description: (2nd c. AD) An ancient Roman monument in the city of Vienne, France. Only a unique vestige of its kind remains visible today, commonly called the Viennese pyramid, and locally simply "the Pyramid" or "the Tomb of Pilate". It is the only ancient Egyptian monument still standing in France. This “pyramid” is in fact a restored stone masonry work resembling the shape of an obelisk, built above a tetrapyle serving as a pedestal. It may have replaced a real obelisk, now lost.

Description: (4th m. BC) An exceptionally dense collection of megalithic sites near the south coast of Brittany in northwestern France, consisting of stone alignments, dolmens, tumuli and single menhirs. More than 3,000 prehistoric standing stones were hewn from local granite and erected by the pre-Celtic people of Brittany and form the largest such collection in the world. Most of the stones are within the Breton municipality of Carnac, but some to the east are within neighboring La Trinité-sur-Mer. The stones were erected at some stage during the Neolithic period, probably around 3300 BC, but some may date to as early as 4500 BC.

properties.description:
Description: (1st c. AD) The ruins of an ancient Roman building built under Augustus. The so-called Temple of Diana is located near the gushing spring of "La Fontaine", around which was an Augusteum, a sanctuary devoted to the cult of the emperor and his family, centred on a nymphaeum. Its basilica-like floor plan argues against it being a temple and there is no archaeological or literary evidence for its dedication to Diana. The building may instead have been a library. Its facade was rebuilt during the 2nd century and in the mediaeval era it housed a monastery, ensuring its survival. Its roof construction consists of several elaborate thick barrel-vaulted rooms, using carefully cut ashlars supporting an upper floor. Partly dug into the side of Mount Cavalier, the building was originally flanked by annexes. The main facade is pierced by three large arches.
Category:
Category (multi):
Location: France
Coordinates: 43.8400746846428, 4.34902504297839

AD) The ruins of an ancient Roman building built under Augustus. The so-called Temple of Diana is located near the gushing spring of "La Fontaine", around which was an Augusteum, a sanctuary devoted to the cult of the emperor and his family, centred on a nymphaeum. Its basilica-like floor plan argues against it being a temple and there is no archaeological or literary evidence for its dedication to Diana. The building may instead have been a library. Its facade was rebuilt during the 2nd century and in the mediaeval era it housed a monastery, ensuring its survival. Its roof construction consists of several elaborate thick barrel-vaulted rooms, using carefully cut ashlars supporting an upper floor. Partly dug into the side of Mount Cavalier, the building was originally flanked by annexes. The main facade is pierced by three large arches.

Description: (6th c. BC-3rd c. AD) Located in the center of the Alpilles mountains, Glanum is a sanctuary town at the crossroads of two ancient routes linking Italy to Spain, one via the Alps. The archaelogical site features the remains of an important Roman settlement. This site includes the ruins of both civic and religious edifices and is unique in Provence. Some traces of occupation date back to the beginning of the 1st millennium BC, and the clearer remains, still sporadic, to the 7th and 6th centuries BC.

Description: (3rd m.-1st c. BC) Ruins of the acropolis of ancient Lilaia. Lilaia was one of the most important ancient Phocian towns and city-state. Its walls and gates are to the east of the modern settlement. Among the visible antiquities of the region count the architectural members by the springs of Agia Eleoussa, where a fountain and the temple of Cephissus lay, as well as the early Byzantine remains of a basilica dedicated to St. Christopher. Another Byzantine church, dated to the 10th-11th century was dedicated to St. Eleoussa. The fortification of the city is evident on the hill "Pyrgos" or "Palaeokastro". During the Frankish period the site was fortified with a new wall.

Description: (1500-400 BC) In Epiros, about 22 km southwest from Ioannina. For over a millennium and until the 4th century BC the sanctuary of Zeus and Dione at Dodona was a renown oracle, second in fame only to Delphi and the host of the Naia festival which included athletic contests and theatrical performances. Its most important ruins include the well preserved Hellenistic Theatre and the foundations of the Hiera Oikia that stood next to the Sacred Oak, as well as the traces of the ancient stadium. A plethora of metal artifacts were unearthed during excavations, the majority of which are exhibited at the Archaeological Museum of Ioannina.

Description: (1300 BC) Mycenaean period archaeological site believed to be the Palace of Homer's epic hero Odysseus on the island of Ithaca. The excavation site is believed to be a large Mycenaean palatial building complex occupying two levels. A stairway cut into the solid bedrock of the hill provided easy access to the two levels. Other finds on the site include a funerary enclosure, a large circular structure whose purpose is unknown, several storerooms and workshops, a sophisticated drainage system and fragments of pottery. The complex also features a well from the 8th century BC, roughly the period in which Odysseus is believed to have been king of Ithaca.

Description: (3000 BC) Argos, located in the Peloponnese in Greece, was a major Mycenaean settlement in the Late Bronze Age and remained important throughout the Greek, Hellenistic, and Roman periods until its destruction by the Visigoths in 395 AD. The site's best-preserved example of ancient architecture is the theatre and the remains of the 2nd-century Roman baths. There are Mycenaean tombs, an odeum, the sanctuary of Aphrodite, the foundations and walls of the agora, and a large stoa or collonaded enclosure.

Description: (9th c. BC) A sanctuary of the goddess Hera situated in a small cove of the Corinthian gulf at the end of the Perachora peninsula. In addition to a temple of Hera of unusual construction and antiquity, the remains of a number of other structures have also been found, including an L-shaped stoa, a large cistern, dining rooms, and a second potential temple. Remains are known to extend for 1.7 km eastward from the sanctuary to a lagoon. The best preserved of these constitute an extensive hydraulic system.
Category:

Description: (1225-1600 AD) A ruined Frankish abbey near Stymfalia, in the Peloponnese, Greece. It was built following the events of the Fourth Crusade in 1204, and the establishment of the Latin Empire of Constantinople and Greece. One of the exceptionally few samples of western Gothic architecture in Greece. The main surviving structures are the vaulted gate house and the church, as well as parts of the defensive wall.

properties.description:
Description: (4th c. BC) A town in the northeast of Arcadia, ancient Greece. Archaeological surveys and excavations have revealed a town refounded in the 4th century BC. The later city was laid out on a grid plan. Houses have been identified, as have a theatre, a palaestra, a fountain house, several temples, and the sanctuary, where an inscription preserving the letters POLIAD ("of Athena Polias"), but now lost, seems to indicate Athena Polias as the divinity worshipped. Four small cemeteries of the late 4th to mid 6th centuries attest to a small scale Late Roman and Early Byzantine settlement in the area although no architectural remains of houses or church have yet been found.

Description: (4th c. BC-3rd c. AD) The Dipylon was the main gate in the city wall of Classical Athens. The gate was of major ceremonial significance as the starting point of the procession of the Great Panathenaea, and accordingly it was a large, monumental structure. Erected in 478 BC as part of Themistocles' fortification of Athens and rebuilt in the 300s BC, it remained standing and in use until the 3rd century.

properties.description:
Description: (9th c. BC-726 AD) Named after the Spartan commander Theras. At its height, Thera boasted sanctuaries, temples, and an impressive theater hewn into rock. Archaeological remains are sparse. Inscriptions from the city's beginnings found at the sanctuary on the spur of the mountain ridge date from the transition from the 9th to the 8th century BC and are thus among the oldest known examples of the use of the Greek alphabet. There are two caves in the vicinity of Ancient Thera, one of which appears to be an additional antique sanctuary and the other either a place of cult worship or simply a garbage pit.
Category:

Location: Greece

properties.description:
Description: (5th c. BC) The Tomb of Leonidas is the only monument preserved from the Ancient Agora. The edifice has the form of a temple probably dating back to the late 5th century BC. Until today, it is not known what the edifice was used for. It is believed to be a cenotaph, while many researchers share the opinion that it is the temple of Karneio Apollo. Although there is no indication on the correlation between the temple and the legendary king of Sparta, according to local tradition and the travel writer Pausanias, the remains of Leonidas were transferred and buried there. It is because of this, that the locals believe it to be the tomb of Leonidas.
Category:
Category (multi): Megalithic stones, Megalithic structures, Necropolis/tombs complex

Description: (650 BC) Sparta was recognized as the leading force of the unified Greek military during the Greco-Persian Wars, in rivalry with the rising naval power of Athens. properties.description:
Description: (7th c. BC-395 AD) The site of the Eleusinian Mysteries and the birthplace of Aeschylus. Eleusis was a deme of ancient Attica, belonging to the phyle Hippothoöntis. It owed its celebrity to its being the chief seat of the worship of Demeter and Persephone, and to the mysteries celebrated in honour of these goddesses, and continued to be regarded as the most sacred of all the Grecian mysteries down to the fall of paganism. The Greek Archaeological Society, excavating the site after 1882, laid bare the whole of the sacred precinct, which included the Great Propylaea, a 2nd century copy of the central building of the Propylaea on the Acropolis of Athens. It also traced its extensions at various periods and revealed successive stages in the structure of the Telesterion, or Hall of Initiation, first built in late Mycenaean times.

Description: (5th c. BC) The deme of Sounion is most well known for its sanctuaries of Poseidon and Athena. An inscription confirms that the temple was dedicated to Poseidon, and it was built upon the remains of an even earlier poros temple whose foundations are still visible. This Archaic temple was razed by the Persians in 490 BC when it was still under construction. Very little is known about this earlier temple. The temple of Poseidon was a peripteral building of the Doric order, made of marble from nearby Agrileza, with six columns at its ends and thirteen on each long side, of which thirteen survive today.

Description: (5th c. BC) Designed by the architect Kallikrates, it was built between 426 and 421 BC. It is the smallest temple on the Acropolis of Athens, dedicated to the goddesses Athena and Nike. The temple is the earliest fully Ionic temple on the Acropolis. There is some archaeological evidence that the location was used for religious rituals already in Mycenaean age. Mycenaeans also raised the first defensive bastion on the spot; its fragments are preserved in the temple’s basement.

Description: (8th c. BC-550 AD) Kamiros, together with Lindos and Ialyssos, represented the most powerful ancient cities of Rhodes. Kamiros was the smallest of these cities and the most agriculturally based. Kamiros was founded by the Dorians, but the area had already been inhabited by Achaeans, as a Mycenaean cemetery has also been found near the city. The discovery of the foundations of large public buildings, an agora, elaborate private dwellings and an acropolis with a sanctuary testify to the importance and wealth of the ancient city. Most of the houses here date back to the Hellenistic and Roman periods, and the town's sewage system has been preserved.

properties.description:
Description: (800-460 BC) An ancient temple in Argos, Greece. It was part of the greatest sanctuary in the Argolid, dedicated to Hera, her protector. Before Argos built the earliest structures of the Heraion and held influence over the area, groups were using the land in the Neolithic period into the Late Helladic period. Based on the remaining structure, it is clear that Argos was emulating the Mycenaean stonework style, Cyclopean masonry.

Description: (1600-1100 BC) The most important and richest palatial centre of the Late Bronze Age in Greece according to Homer. The site preserves the ruins of the city that dominated the eastern Mediterranean world from the 15th to the 12th century BC. Things of interest are The Lion Gate, the Cyclopean Walls, Grave Circles A and B, the Palace of Mycenae, the Underground Cistern, the Tomb of Clytemnestra, the Tomb of Aegisthus, the Lion Tholos Tomb, and the Treasury of Atreus.

properties.description:
Description: Age is undetermined but archaeologists. Built entirely of gray limestone quarried in the region, with large blocks in a trapezoidal and partially polygonal system. The pyramid’s external sides slope and surround a rectangular area of total dimensions 7.03 by 9.07 metres. These external walls, which rise with a gradient of 60 degrees to a height of 3.50 metres become vertical to in order to support the upper platform of the building, which was probably used as a surveillance spot. The main entrance of the monument is situated at its eastern side, which overlooks the gulf of the Argolid.

properties.description:
Description: (5th c. BC) The official meeting place of the Athenian Democratic Assembly. Three phases can be distinguished in the archaeology; (I. Early 5th century BC) (II. Late 5th century BC) (III. around 345-335 BC). The southern side of the auditorium and speaker's platform were quarried out of the natural bedrock. Traces of the quarrying process can still be seen at the eastern side of the great rock-cut scarp. It is unknown for how many years Pnyx III was used as the meeting place of the ekklesia, and certainly by the 1st century BC the assembly held their meetings in the Theater of Dionysos on the South Slope of the Acropolis.
Category:
Category (multi): Megalithic stones, Megalithic structures
Location: Greece
Coordinates: 37.97161208120538, 23.719768590854365
Source: https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Pnyx

Description: (5th c. AD) An ancient home for rich and elite Maya people, this small archeological site was once joined to the Grand Plaza of Copan via a raised causeway. Remnants of luxurious living quarters in the exclusive compound include intricate reliefs, tombs built into family homes, and a main structure adorned with life-sized figures in feathered headdresses. Las Sepulturas translates to “the Tombs”; a name given to the site by local farmers who discovered an abundance of tombs around the area.

Description: (2nd c. BC-3rd c. AD) A fort located near the Village Hadsar, Junnar, which was meant for the protection of the ancient commercial trade route from Mawal region to Kalyan via Naneghat. The entrance gate, rooms for sentries, water cisterns, steps to the fort are all chiselled from single rock. There is temple of Mahdev at the top of the fort. There are stone cut idols of Ganesh, Garud and Hanuman in the temple. There is a big lake on the fort.

Description: (8th c. AD) Also referred to as the Rock-cut Temples at Masrur, is a complex of rock-cut Hindu temples in the Kangra Valley of Beas River in Himachal Pradesh, India. They are a version of North Indian Nagara architecture style, dedicated to Shiva, Vishnu, Devi and Saura traditions of Hinduism, with its surviving iconography likely inspired by a henotheistic framework. The temples are carved out of monolithic rock.

properties.description:
Description: (3rd-7th c. AD) An ancient rock-cut caves site, located near Dhank village. The caves have been chiseled out of a calcareous sandstone, with a plain style of carving, and is of Buddhist and Jain influences. The Jain cave includes figures of Adinath, Shantinath and Pārśva. These are considered to be the earliest Jain sculptures in Kathiawad of the 7th century period. Much of the sculptures are defaced and eroded over years.

properties.description:
Description: (4th-5th c. AD) A monolithic example of Indian rock-cut architecture carved out of a solid sandstone on a hillside, and one of the finest testimonials to ancient Viswakarma Sthapathis. They are associated with the Vishnukundin Kings of 420-620 AD. There are several caves and the best known largest one has four stories with a huge recreated statue of Vishnu in a reclining posture, sculpted from a single block of granite inside the second floor. It was originally a Hindu cave resembling the architecture of Udayagiri and Khandagiri.

properties.description:
Description: (13th c. AD) A Sun temple attributed to King Narasimhadeva I of the Eastern Ganga dynasty. Dedicated to the Hindu Sun God Surya, what remains of the temple complex has the appearance of a 30 metre high chariot with immense wheels and horses, all carved from stone. Much of the temple is now in ruins. The structures and elements that have survived are famed for their intricate artwork, iconography, and themes, including erotic kama and mithuna scenes. Also called the Surya Devalaya, it is a classic illustration of the Odisha style of Architecture or Kalinga architecture.

properties.description:
Description: (12th c. AD) Monuments and buildings from the Delhi Sultanate at Mehrauli in Delhi, India. The complex contains masterpieces of Indo-Islamic art and remnants of far older civilizations. Its centerpiece is the Qutub Minar, an exquisitely decorated minaret that dates from the early 1200s. The complex also includes two mosques, one of which, the Quwwatu’l-Islam, is the oldest mosque in northern India. Other structures in the complex include the Alai Darwaza gate, the Alai Minar and the Iron pillar.

properties.description:
Description: (322-185 BC) The Barabar Caves were called "Marabar Caves" after serving as the setting for the book and film "A Passage to India". Located in Jehanabad district, India. The Barabar Hill Caves are the oldest surviving rock-cut caves in India, dating from the Maurya Empire. The caves were used by ascetics from the Ajivika sect, founded by Makkhali Gosala, a contemporary of Gautama Buddha, the founder of Buddhism, and of Mahavira, the last and 24th Tirthankara of Jainism. Most caves at Barabar consist of two chambers, carved entirely out of granite, with a highly polished internal surface.

Category (multi): Cave Structures
Location: India

Source: https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Barabar_Caves

Description: (6th-10th c. AD) One of the largest rock-cut Hindu temple cave complexes in the world, with artwork dating from the period 600-1000 AD. There are over 100 caves at the site, all excavated from the basalt cliffs in the Charanandri Hills, 34 of which are open to the public. All of the Ellora monuments were built during the Rashtrakuta dynasty, which constructed part of the Hindu and Buddhist caves, and the Yadava dynasty, which constructed a number of the Jain caves.

Description: (8th c. AD) The largest of the rock-cut Hindu temples at the Ellora Caves. It is a megalith carved from a rock cliff face, considered one of the most remarkable cave temples in the world because of its size, architecture and sculptural treatment, and "the climax of the rock-cut phase of Indian architecture". The Kailasa temple (Cave 16) is the largest of the 34 Buddhist, Jain and Hindu cave temples and monasteries of Ellora Caves complex.
Category:

It was the name of a Zoroastrian sacred fire of the highest grade (Atash Behram), which served as one of the three most sacred fires of pre-Islamic Iran; the two others being the Adur Farnbag and Adur Burzen-mihr. Out of the three, Adur Gushnasp is the only fire whose temple structure has been discovered and "for which archaeological, sigillographical, and textual evidence are all available." IThe temple served as a prominent site of pilgrimage.

properties.description:
Description: (6th c. BC) The final resting place of Cyrus the Great, the founder of the ancient Achaemenid Empire. The mausoleum is located in Pasargadae, an archaeological site in the Fars Province of Iran. The mausoleum is a significant historical example of earthquake engineering, as it is said to be the oldest base-isolated structure in the world, allowing it great resilience against seismic hazards.

Description: (6th-5th c. BC) The site is home to two trilingual Achaemenid cuneiform inscriptions, carved in stone, in 20 lines, on a granite rock above a creek, measuring 2 × 3 metres each. Written in Old Persian, Neo-Babylonian and Neo-Elamite, except for the different royal name, the contents of the two inscriptions are identical. The site received its name from local natives, who believed that the inscriptions contained the secret code to a hidden treasure.

properties.description:
Description: (8th-6th c. BC) An archaeological site and open air sanctuary. Six Elamite rock reliefs are located in a small gorge marked by a seasonal creek bed on the plain's east side of the valley, near the town of Izeh in Khuzestan. The reliefs exhibit a cuniform inscription, processions, the sacrifice of animals, musical performances, and banqueting. The specific location of the reliefs suggests that Kul-e Farah must have enjoyed a particular religious significance; perhaps of transcendent nature.

Description: (5th c. BC) Also known as the Gate of Xerxes, in the ruins of the ancient city of Persepolis. Located north of the Apadana, a broad stairway descends. Xerxes, who built this structure, named it “The Gate of All Countries,” for all visitors had to pass through this, the only entrance to the terrace, on their way to the Throne Hall to pay homage to the king. The gate was flanked by two monumental statues of lamassu, winged bulls with human heads, who were thought to ward off evil.

properties.description:
Description: (12th-7th c. BC) “Salomon’s Cave”. Carved inside a rectangular panel about 8.5 meters above ground level, it depicts two men, a boy, and a woman standing in profile oriented toward the cave making worship gestures before a fire stand. It seems that the original panel, which dates to around the 12th century, had shown only the royal family and that the fire stand and the man closest to it were 11th-7th century additions. A poorly preserved Elamite inscription added to the relief in the 7th-6th century BC by Hanni, kutur (caretaker, protector, ruler) of Ayapir extends over the lower part of the relief.
Category:
Category (multi): Cave Structures
Location: Iran
Coordinates: 31.81669305077573, 49.848460698250534
Source: https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Eshkaft-e_Salman

Description: An ancient graveyard. The Graveyard of the Scene is the same tomb of the governor of Kayavus in the Achaemenid dynasty, which is 15 metres high, with two rooms and three tombs, two of which belong to the servants or servants of Kay Kawus in the first room to accompany him, and Gaurasli in the grand and large room below the first room. It is 24 square metres.

properties.description:
Description: (4th c. AD) A site with a series of large rock reliefs from the era of the Sassanid Empire of Persia. This example of Persian Sassanid art is located 5 km from the city center of Kermanshah. It is located in the heart of the Zagros mountains, where it has endured almost 1,700 years of wind and rain. The Taq-e Bostan complex comprise a rock relief standing on its own and several more reliefs associated with two rock-cut arches. They illustrate the investiture ceremonies of the kings Ardashir II, Shapur II, Shapur III and Khosrau II. They also depict the hunting scenes of Khosrau II.

Description: (6th c. BC) A great stone platform on the western slope of a natural hill. It is 80 metres in length and 15 metres in height. It has been made up of some 20 layers of huge stone slabs having up to six tons weight. The "Throne" hill was almost certainly intended to serve as a platform for further impressive construction; and this never-finished project might have partly provided an inspiration for the later, elevated palatial compound at Persepolis.

Description: (880 BC-5th c. AD) The Prison of Solomon is a hollow cone shaped hill. It is an 80 meters deep pit in the middle of the hill, and the entrance to the pit is roughly 65 meters in diameter. Its current name "Prison of Solomon" was given to it by locals who think it is the place Solomon kept demons prisoner. It used to be surrounded by walls and hosted a Mannaean temple.

properties.description:
Description: (3rd-10th c. AD) An ancient city in Sasanid Persia on the ancient road between Persis and Elam. Bishapur was built near a river crossing and at the same site there is also a fort with rock-cut reservoirs and a river valley with six Sassanid rock reliefs. The most important point about this city, is the combination of Persian and Roman art and architecture that hadn't been seen before Bishapur construction. Bishapour is the first Persian city with vertical and horizontal streets. Also in the city, especially in interior design, you can see tile work that's adapted from Roman Art.

properties.description:
Description: (6th c.-331 BC)) The ruins of a large hypostyle hall. It belongs to the oldest building phase of the city and was the largest building on the Terrace. The Apadana at Persepolis has a surface of 1000 square metres; its roof was supported by 72 columns, each 24 metres tall. The entire hall was destroyed in 331 BC by the army of Alexander the Great. Stones from the columns were used as building material for nearby settlements. By the start of the 20th century, only 13 of these giant columns were still standing. The re-erecting of a complete, but fallen column in the 1970s, is now the 14th standing column of the Apadana.

Location: Iran

Source: https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Apadana

Description: (883-859 BC) The Neo-Assyrian King Ashurnasirpal II built his magnificent Northwest Palace at Nimrud. Interior decoration of the palace features a series of remarkable carved stone panels. The detailed reliefs on display in Rooms 7-8 originally stood in the palace throne-room and in other royal apartments. They depict the king and his subjects engaged in a variety of activities. Ashurnasirpal is shown leading military campaigns against his enemies, engaging in ritual scenes with protective demons and hunting.

Location: Iraq

Description: (50-56 AD) A rock-cut funerary complex in East Jerusalem believed to be the burial site of Queen Helene of Adiabene. The tombs are located 820 metres north of Jerusalem's Old City walls in the Sheikh Jarrah neighborhood. The grandeur of the site led to the belief that the tombs had once been the burial place of the kings of Judah, hence the name Tombs of the Kings; but the tombs are now associated with Queen Helena of Adiabene.

Description: (4th-7th c. AD) The remains of an ancient synagogue. It is also believed to be the site of the large Jewish village of Anaya during the Roman-Byzantine period. It consists of a rectangular prayer hall orientated towards Jerusalem, an entrance portico and a courtyard with rooms on both sides. Hewn stone walls still stand to a height of 3.5 meters and two entrances on the east side survive with their lintels intact. Evidence of a mosaic floor was found beneath the current stone slab flooring and fragments of an inscription remain.

Description: (2nd c. AD) The importance, value and renown of Bet She’arim were due to the fact that it was home to a great rabbi; Rabbi Yehuda HaNasi, who was the religious, spiritual and political leader of the Jewish people at the time, and compiler of the Mishnah (the oral laws). Consisting of a series of catacombs, the necropolis developed as the primary Jewish burial place outside of Jerusalem following the failure of the second Jewish revolt against Roman rule. Located southeast of the city of Haifa, these catacombs are a treasury of artworks and inscriptions in Greek, Aramaic, Hebrew and Palmyrene.

properties.description:
Description: (1538 AD) One of the seven main open gates of the Old City of Jerusalem. The name Jaffa Gate is currently used for both the historical Ottoman gate from 1538, and for the wide gap in the city wall adjacent to it to the south. The old gate has the shape of a medieval gate tower with an L-shaped entryway, which was secured at both ends with heavy doors. The breach in the wall was created by the Ottoman authorities in order to allow German emperor Wilhelm II to enter the city triumphally.

Description: (520 AD) The only eastern gate of the Temple Mount, and one of only two gates of the Old City of Jerusalem that used to offer access into the city from the East side. Christians and Muslims generally believe that this was the gate through which Jesus entered Jerusalem. The Golden Gate represents a rectangular stonework structure with two decorated facades.

Description: (4th m. BC-7th c. AD) An archaeological site considered by most scholars to be the original settlement core of Jerusalem during the Bronze and Iron Ages. The remains at the site include several water tunnels, several pools including the Pool of Siloam, and in its vicinity the remains of the Acra, a fortress built by Antiochus Epiphanes to subdue those Jerusalemites who were opposed to Hellenisation. City of David archaeologist Eilat Mazar believes that a so-called Large Stone Structure she has discovered at the upper area of the site and tentatively dated to the 10th to 9th century BC, may be the palace of King David.

Description: (23 BC-71 AD) A desert fortress built by King Herod on a truncated-cone-shaped hill. The park consists of Lower Herodium: a complex that includes the ruins of the palace, a large pool, bath house, and buildings from the time of Herod. It can be seen from the path going up to the top of Herodium. Mt Herod: a partly man-made mountain, on which are the remains of Herod’s palace, bath house, and fortifications, including a double fortification wall and sturdy towers. Herod’s tomb: built on the outer slope of the hill, facing Jerusalem. A small theatre,and escape tunnels, cisterns and caves carved out by the Bar Kochba rebels.

Description: (1830 BC) Alatri, Lazio, central Italy. It belonged to the confederation of the Hernici, an ancient people of Italy, and later passed under the dominion of Rome. Archaeologically the town is of significance for its great belt of cyclopean walls that enclose the trapezoid Pelasgian acropolis, the walls of which are almost intact. The outer circle of walls, supplemented at intervals by medieval towers, is penetrated by three massive gates. Other important buildings are the Casagrandi Palace, the Bishop’s Palace, the Episcopal Seminary, and the cathedral.

It belonged to the confederation of the Hernici, an ancient people of Italy, and later passed under the dominion of Rome. Description: (5th m. BC) Also known as the "Fairy's Houses" are monuments linked to the mysterious cult that dug the rock to build eternal houses for their dead. The Domus de Janas "S'Incantu" is also called the "painted tomb" and it is considered the queen of the domus de Janas because of its beauty and symmetry: its interior is cararcterised by a double sloping roof dug in rock, with majestic columns and many symbols carved in trachyte, symbols associated with a prehistoric cult.

Description: (5th c. BC-2nd c. AD) The ancient city of Norba stands out the hills of Lazio, with its monumental walls and many remains of its past. Norba was inhabited for 7 centuries in which it was an unassailable citadel, during some of the most important wars in the republican age of Rome. The rich and glorious past of the city are still visible in the architectural structures. There are splendid private domus with gardens, decoration and mosaic, and great public constructions, for example the vast baths.

properties.description:
Description: (8th-7th c. BC) An ancient tower. The Torre di Cicerone stands on the so-called Acropolis of Arpino. On the main floor of the tower an educational section has been set up that illustrates the history of the monument and the territory, from the Cyclopean walls to the events of the city through its most illustrious men in history and art. The Acropolis of Arpino is one of the most important archaeological sites for the knowledge of the megalithic architecture of southern Lazio, not only for the great extension of the walls but also for the period to which their construction dates back, which according to some can be placed to the Iron Age.
Category:
Category (multi): Megalithic structures, Megalithic stones
Location: Italy

Description: (2000 BC) An ancient rock settlement. The site develops along the Canalotto valley and bears witness to the Byzantine domination first, and then to the Arabs in the Sicilian territory. The site is made up of a series of rooms dug out of the rock on which Byzantine churches can be seen with their colombariums, millstones and the actual village. The traces found show the organization of the daily life of the community which was maintained even in the Arab era, when the qanat was built .

properties.description:
Description: (11th c. BC) An archaeological area. The site essentially consists of two parts: the first, the best known and most studied, consisting of the well temple, a sacred well dating back to the Nuragic age, with annexed structures: meeting hut, enclosure and other smaller huts. The second part of the complex about two hundred meters to the southwest consists of a single-tower nuraghe, some elongated stone huts of uncertain date and a nuragic village, still to be excavated, of which only a few outcropping elements are visible.

Description: (105-113 AD) The last of the Imperial Fora to be constructed in ancient Rome. To build this monumental complex, extensive excavations were required: workers eliminated a ridge connecting the Quirinal and Capitoline Hills. Over 300,000 cubic metres of soil and rock were excavated and dumped outside the Porta Collina.

Description: (6th-2nd c. BC) an ancient settlement. The settlement stood on the Via Clodia and occupied a narrow plateau at the confluence of the Pile and Acqualta ditches in the Biedano stream. Norchia plateau is dominated by the ruins of the medieval settlement, with the Parish Church of San Pietro, the castle and the watchtower. Norchia's fame is closely linked to the spectacular rocky necropoli that surround it, which show the display of a wealth, linked to the social class of the agricultural aristocracy, who wanted to distinguish themselves publicly. The variety of architectural types is vast, the facade tombs are in two or three orders, arranged on steps which are partly natural, partly built, modifying the morphological aspect of the slopes of the plains.
Category:
Category (multi): Necropolis/tombs complex
Location: Italy
Coordinates: 42.338585993755345, 11.946247760169742
Source: https://www.passaggilenti.com/norchia-necropoli-etrusche/

properties.description:
Description: (12th-16th c. AD) Bramafam Tower stands along the southern side of the Roman walls. It has a circular rampart, with the Roman walls still visible at its base, and part of the tower which flanked Porta Principalis Dextera, on which it was constructed. It belonged to the family of the Viscounts of Aosta, who controlled the entire south-western side of the walls. Over the subsequent centuries it underwent various other property changes, and lost its representative and administrative importance. It was apparently abandoned in the 16th century.

Description: (27 BC-10 c. AD) The triumphal Arch of Augustus, located in the Roman Forum. It is one of the oldest Roman arches which survives to this day. The huge arch is flanked by two engaged columns with fluted shafts and Corinthian capitals. The four clipei placed next to the capitals each depict Roman divinities: Jupiter and Apollo on the Roman side, Neptune and Roma facing the city of Rimini.

properties.description:
Description: (5th c. BC) An ancient acropolis located in the Selinunte Archaeological Park. The Acropolis is placed on the hill between the Modione and the Cottone, where the port of the city was located. It has been deduced that the civil houses after 409 BC were small buildings with a door on the street and a 4 to 9 metre long façade. There are fortifications winding around the acropolis in square blocks, restored several times: the development of the walls was interrupted by towers, and by gates at the ends of the main arteries and postern. The north gate appears strengthened. On the hill of the acropolis, the remains of five temples of the Doric order have been found.

properties.description:
Description: (515-86 BC) The Temple of the Olympian Zeus. During the Hellenistic and Roman period it was the largest temple in Greece. Its construction was begun on the ruins of a pre-existing temple by the Pisistratid tyrants, but was abandoned shortly after. When Greece was incorporated into the Roman Empire, Hadrian dedicated the temple to Zeus. He had a chrysoelephantine gold and ivory statue of Zeus erected in the cell and, not far from this, a statue of him as big as that of the god. However, nothing remains of the inside of the temple, destroyed by the barbarians and used as a stone quarry.
Category:
Category (multi): Temple complex
Location: Italy

Description: (6th c. BC) A peripteral Doric temple. It is the oldest temple in Magna Graecia and the only Greek religious structure still visible in the old town of Taranto. The temple fell into ruin in the Middle Ages and parts of it were reused in the construction of other buildings. The devastation and ruination experienced by the temple over the centuries, especially the phenomenon of spoliation, has made it impossible to outline an exact plan of the temple.

properties.description:
Description: (2nd m. BC) A Nuraghic well temple dating back to the Bronze Age. The temple has a distinctive keyhole-shaped entrance, with stairs leading down to the well bottom; all oriented in such a way that on the day of the summer solstice, sunlight shines directly down the well shaft. The temple was built in opus isodoma, with masterfully squared basalt blocks, and worked if necessary with an appropriate inclination. The rocks present in the surrounding area are mainly composed of schists or granites, and the volcanic rock used was transported to the site from rather distant locations, probably from the Dorgali area.

properties.description:
Description: (18th c. BC-2nd c. AD) An ancient Nuragic monument. It represents one of the finest examples of architecture connected to the cult of water. The wall structures were built in the isodomic technique with perfectly squared limestone ashlars, probably extracted from the quarries of the nearby town of Laerru. The sacred well is part of a complex that includes the remains of an enclosure made with large blocks of trachyte, built on the ruins of a pre-existing megaron temple. In the immediate vicinity there are also the remains of some huts, with superimpositions of houses from the Roman age.

The sacred well is part of a complex that includes the remains of an enclosure made with large blocks of trachyte, built on the ruins of a pre-existing megaron temple. In the immediate vicinity there are also the remains of some huts, with superimpositions of houses from the Roman age.

properties.name: Pozzo Sacro del Predio Canopoli

properties.description:
Description: (6th c. AD) A stone kofun of the Asuka period. The kofun is believed to be the tomb of Soga no Umako. It is the largest known megalithic structure in Japan. It was built on a spur of a mountain that falls northeast to a small plateau. It consists of a platform, a gallery entryway, stone walls that form a tomb, two large stones that form a ceiling for the tomb, and embankments on either side of the tomb. The large granite megaliths come from Mount Tōnomine, which is approximately 3 km from the site.

Description: (1st c. AD) An ancient temple dedicated to the Olympian Zeus. It was built on a high pedestal that makes it visible from many parts of the town. properties.description:
Description: (7th m. BC) The ruins of an ancient city. The earliest evidence of settlement is in a Neolithic site known as Tal Abu Sowan, where rare human remains dating to around 7500 BC were uncovered. Jerash flourished during the Greek, Hellenistic, Roman, and Byzantine periods until the 749 Galilee earthquake which destroyed large parts of it. In the year 1120, Zahir ad-Din Toghtekin, atabeg of Damascus ordered a garrison of forty men to build up a fort in an unknown site of the ruins of the ancient city, likely the highest spot of the city walls in the north-eastern hills. It was captured in 1121 by Baldwin II, King of Jerusalem, and utterly destroyed. Then, the Crusaders immediately abandoned Jerash.

properties.description:
Description: (2nd c. BC) A historic and archaeological city known for its Hellenistic architecture. Petra was the capital of the Nabataean Kingdom and the centre of their caravan trade. Excavations have demonstrated that it was the ability of the Nabataeans to control the water supply that led to the rise of the desert city, creating an artificial oasis. The area is visited by flash floods, but archaeological evidence shows that the Nabataeans controlled these floods by the use of dams, cisterns, and water conduits. These innovations stored water for prolonged periods of drought and enabled the city to prosper.

properties.description:
Description: (13th c. AD) A castle built by the Crusaders as a fortress of the holy land. Today, the castle consists primarily of two towers connected by a wall. In the outer walls, Roman columns were used as horizontal reinforcements. The rectangular west tower is the better preserved of the two. There is a large vaulted room scattered with old carved capitals and rusting cannonballs. A winding staircase leads up to the roof, where there is a small, domed Ottoman-era mosque. The east tower isn't as well preserved and was built in two phases; the lower part dates to the Crusader period, while the upper level was built by the Mamluks. There has also been evidence of the old Phoenician city being buried under the sea in the area surrounding the castle with structures of walls, columns, stairways, the remains of buildings, statues and cisterns.
Category:
Category (multi):
Location: Lebanon
Coordinates: 33.56733089336784, 35.37096856441779
Source: https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Sidon_Sea_Castle
Images: https://upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/f/f5/SidonSeaCastle.jpg

properties.description:
Description: (9th c. BC-6th c. AD) A world heritage site in the city of Tyre. The necropolis, constituting the principal entrance of the town in antique times, is to be found on either side of a wide Roman and Byzantine avenue dominated by a triumphal arch. Other important monumental vestiges of this archaeological area are an aqueduct, and a hippodrome. The necropolis consists of hundreds of stone and marble sarcophagi from the Roman and Byzantine eras. Several of them have Greek inscriptions or the names of those buried there, or their trade. Others have sides and covers that are decorated with frescoes and bas-reliefs. The Triumphal Arch, which had fallen apart but was reconstructed in modern times, dominates the well preserved Roman avenue which has a necropolis on either side scattered with hundreds of ornate stones and sculptured marble sarcophagi. In the northern section of the site there is a Phoenician necropolis formed by dug graves containing urns.
Category:
Category (multi): Necropolis/tombs complex
Location: Lebanon
Coordinates: 33.27005399552898, 35.198171921538986
Source: https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Tyre_Necropolis
Images: https://upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/c/c0/Al-Bass_Arch_Site_P1010056.JPG

Description: (3rd -4th c. AD) Hammara temple is the site of a Roman shrine upon which a Christian church was later constructed. The shrine, square in shape, consisted of an altar surrounded by sixteen pillars and set inside a larger enclosure. According to several architrave inscriptions, the edifice was dedicated to the God Zeus. Following the Doric order, studies have shown that the temple was remodeled several times since its construction.

properties.description:
Description: (2nd c. AD) The ruins of an ancient Roman temple. The temple was built on a high platform, reached by a wide flight of steps. The façade has collapsed and the Corinthian columns are now gone, but the impressive fronton, which used to face the rising sun, has been reconstructed by the excavators. In front of the sanctuary are the remains of an altar, hardly anything of it is preserved. What has been uncovered is only the top level of the temple, the rest of which is believed to be buried under the entire village. Aside from the temple, there is al-Maqtaa, the stone quarry, where the Romans cut the stones they used for building the temple, plus several ancient tombs are also visible in the neighborhood of the sanctuary.

Description: (12th c. AD) A Crusader castle which belonged to the Genoese Embriaco family, Lords of the city. The castle was built from indigenous limestone and the remains of Roman structures.
