properties.description:
Description: (3300-3000 BC) A neolithic subterranean structure dating to the Saflieni phase in Maltese prehistory. The Hypogeum is thought to have been a sanctuary and necropolis with the remains of more than 7,000 people documented, and is among the best preserved examples of the Maltese temple building culture that also produced the megalithic temples and Xagħra Stone Circle. The Hypogeum is constructed entirely underground and consists of three superimposed levels hewn into soft globigerina limestone, with its halls and chambers interconnected through a labyrinthine series of steps, lintels and doorways. The upper level is thought to have been occupied first, with the middle and lower levels expanded and excavated later. Some of the middle chambers appear to share stylistic characteristics with the contemporaneous megalithic temples found across Malta.
Category:
Category (multi): Megalithic structures, Megalithic stones, Necropolis/tombs complex
Location: Malta
Coordinates: 35.86967914722496, 14.506891422088946
Source: https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/%C4%A6al_Saflieni_Hypogeum
Images: https://www.qualityassuredmalta.com/wp-content/uploads/2019/06/Hypogeum-11-of-11-1600x1000.jpg

properties.description:
Description: (4th m. BC) A megalithic temple complex. Mnajdra is made of coralline limestone. The main structural systems used in the temples are corbelling with smaller stones, and post and lintel construction using large slabs of limestone. The structure consists of three temples, conjoined, but not connected: the upper (the oldest), middle, and lower. The lowest temple is astronomically aligned and thus was probably used as an astronomical observation and/or calendrical site. properties.description:
Description: A prominent circular geological feature in the Sahara's Adrar Plateau. It is an eroded geological dome, 40 km in diameter, exposing sedimentary rock in layers which appear as concentric rings. Igneous rock is exposed inside and there are rhyolites and gabbros which have undergone hydrothermal alteration, and a central megabreccia. The structure is also the location of accumulations of Acheulean archaeological artifacts, as well as being one of the places the famed Atlantis existed.

Location: Mauritania

Description: (1180-1628 AD) Nan Madol forms an archaeological district covering more than 18 square km and includes stone architecture built up on a coral reef, flat along the shore of Temwen Island, several other artificial islets, and the adjacent Pohnpei main island coastline. The site core with its stone walls encloses an area approximately 1.5 by 0.5 km containing nearly 100 artificial islets; stone and coral fill platforms bordered by tidal canals. Nan Madol has been interpreted by some as the remains of one of the "lost continents" of Lemuria or Mu.

Description: (4th-3rd c. BC) An archaeological site of a stone circle in northern Morocco. It is located near Chouahed village, 15 kilometres southeast of Asilah, and consists of 167 monoliths surrounding a tumulus 58 metres long by 54 metres wide, with a height of 6 metres. One of the monoliths, known as El Uted (the peg) measures more than 5 metres, with the average height of the monoliths being 1.5 metres. Legend claims it is the tomb of the giant Antaeus. Dated to the 4th or 3rd century BC, the site probably hints to the beginnings of the Kingdom of Mauretania.

Description: (3rd c. BC) The Roman remains of a fortified municipality built on an imposing site at the foot of Jebel Zerhoun. It is of exceptional significance in that it shows urban development and Romanization at the borders of the Roman Empire and graphically illustrates the interface between Roman and indigenous cultures. The archaeological remains of this site testify to several civilizations from prehistory to the Islamic period. The site has yielded considerable artistic documentation which includes mosaics, marble and bronze statues and hundreds of inscriptions.

Description: An archaeological cave site. The caves are carved into solid conglomerate rocks at several levels, and are connected by pathways. All the caves have small rooms with hearths and wall niches for lamps, along with verandahs or front porches. During British rule, around 1500 caves were reported, but now only 500 remain. The caves are in poor condition and are slowly eroding. No conservation efforts have been made to protect the site due to poor accessibility and lack of knowledge of the archaeological site.

Description: (13th-16th c. AD) Chinchero was on the direct road that in Inca times led directly to Machu Picchu and was an important urban center that we can still see today around its church and square. In its surroundings there are formidable walls of assembled polyhedrons that form retaining walls giving shape to the platforms, there are also large rooms with windows, niches, doors and accesses. Also in the area are the remains of three shrines called Titiqaqa, Pumaqaqa, Chincana; which are huge outcrops of limestone rock carefully carved by the ancient Peruvians, in the form of seats, stairways, cupboards and channels. There is a group of platforms built obeying the conformation of the terrain.

Description: (13th-16th c. AD) An ancient Inca ritual stone. Also known as the “Solar Clock”, it is a piece carved in stone in the shape of a polygon. According to historians it was used to record the passage of time and assist in the control of agricultural cycles.

properties.description:
Description: (15th c. AD) An important ceremonial center built during the reign of the Incan Pachacutec. Apparently, the Tarawasi site had another purpose during the pre-Columbian era since it was mainly constructed as a Tambo, a place used as a resting point for travelers and the Chaskis, who were the messengers of the Incas. The site has an extraordinary architecture style, where its walls are made with perfectly carved stones with an octagonal shape. The Incas managed to put them together without the need of any type of mortar. Likewise, the structure is composed of agricultural terraces with their respective irrigation channels that supplied water to the whole precinct. There’s also an important altar called “Usnu,” which was located on top of the ceremonial center.
Category:
Category (multi): Temple complex, Polygonal masonry
Location: Peru
Coordinates: -13.468496590871359, -72.43613223983026
Source:

properties.description:
Description: (6th-11th c. AD) A sacred Inca archaeological site. Naupa Iglesia is a cave whose flat stone surfaces form an inverted “V”. On a rock face of the cave there is an extremely precise "false door" which leads nowhere. In front of the cave stands an abstract, symmetrical, stepped sculpture in black granite, which has been badly damaged. It is flanked by a wall consisting of two rows of four niches of a certain type. The niches in this wall are Tiwanaku 4 style niches. Immediately to the north of the cave there is a small building structure with niches, doors and windows in masonry.
Category:
Category (multi):
Location: Peru
Coordinates: -13.288561285592422, -72.2295330072966
Source: https://fr.wikipedia.org/wiki/Naupa_Iglesia

properties.description:
Description: (1500-300 BC) An archaeological site (or archaeological monument). It was the administrative and religious center of the Chavín culture and its structures, shaped like a truncated pyramid, are built with stone and mud mortar. The construction presents a complex network of paths and interior stone galleries only illuminated by beams of light that penetrate through strategically arranged ducts. Inside you can still see the monolithic Lanzón, a carved stone 4.54 metres high in which an anthropomorphic divinity is represented. On the walls of the main temple you may see a series of nail heads, sculptural lumps that apparently acted as mythological guardians of the temple. The most imposing structure in the complex is known as “El Castillo”. It is an outstanding example of the art of building of the ancient Peruvians due to the high degree of perfection achieved in terms of engineering, in the carving and polishing of stones and in the lithosculpture associated with its architecture.
Category:
Category (multi): Temple complex, Megalithic stones
Location: Peru
Coordinates: -9.593375893829693, -77.17666784777639
Source: https://es.wikipedia.org/wiki/Chav%C3%ADn_de_Hu%C3%A1ntar
Images: https://upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/a/a6/Chav%C3%ADn_de_Hu%C3%A1ntar_-_51148181187.jpg

properties.description:
Description: A large archaeological site. The ruins of Huánuco Pampa lie on a plateau and it is one of at least six sites that were called New Cuscos, built in the conceptual, if not actual, image of the capital. The city covered about 2-square-kilometers, within which more than 4,000 buildings were erected. Pathways radiate out through architectural sectors from the plaza, so that the city can easily be divided up to 12 parts. The ceremonial sections of Huánuco Pampa display rare, finely cut and fitted, Imperial Inca style masonry and appear as unusual building types.
Category:
Category (multi): Temple complex, Megalithic structures, Megalithic stones
Location: Peru
Coordinates: -9.875013273631971, -76.81219013613216
Source: https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Hu%C3%A1nuco_Pampa

properties.description:
Description: (15th-16th c. AD) The most important temple in the Inca Empire, dedicated to Inti, the Incan sun god. To construct Coricancha, the Inca used ashlar masonry, building from the placement of similarly sized cuboid stones that they had cut and shaped for this purpose. The use of ashlar masonry made the temple much more difficult to construct, as the Inca did not use any stone with a slight imperfection or break. By choosing this masonry type, the Inca intentionally demonstrated the importance of the building through the extent of the labor necessary to build the structure.
Category:
Category (multi): Temple complex
Location: Peru
Coordinates: -13.520121753340323, -71.97467063613215
Source: https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Coricancha
Images: https://upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/d/dd/Coricancha%2C_Cusco%2C_Per%C3%BA%2C_2015-07-31%2C_DD_68.JPG

properties.description:
Description: (6th-10th c. AD) A pre-Inca cemetery. The tombs, which are built above ground in chullpas, are the vestiges of the Qulla people. The structures housed the remains of complete family groups, although they were probably limited to nobility. Many of the tombs have been dynamited by grave robbers, while others were left unfinished. The architecture of the site is often considered more complex than typical Incan architecture. In contrast with the Inca, who used stones of varying shapes, the Colla used even rectangular edges.
Category:
Category (multi): Necropolis/tombs complex
Location: Peru
Coordinates: -15.721251360320078, -70.15853095332353
Source: https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Sillusta

Description: (1100-1450 AD) An archaeological site with chullpa and cave paintings. It is one of the most important pre-Hispanic burial grounds on the Andean plateau. It belonged to the Lupaca and Colla realms. Although there is evidence of rock art that is 8000 years old, the main structures were built between 1100 and 1450 AD. There are also remains from the age of the Incas. Chullpas or pucullos. On site are the large funerary towers that dominate the landscape.
Category:
Category (multi): Necropolis/tombs complex
Location: Peru
Coordinates: -16.020567856972775, -70.00466066681679
Source: https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Cutimbo

Description: An Inca archaeological site. The site is regarded as a center of religious worship for Inca people, focusing on water. An important feature on the site is the Sayhuite monolith; an enormous rock containing more than 200 geometric and zoomorphic figures, including reptiles, frogs, and felines. Found at the top of a hill named Concacha, the stone was sculpted as a topographical hydraulic model, complete with terraces, ponds, rivers, tunnels, and irrigation channels.

properties.description:
Description: A huge rock formation in which the Incas carved benches, steps, altars, and various other ceremonial features. In addition are the natural slides that undulate their way down the hill. Built by the Killke culture and later expanded by the Incas. It is a huge geological formation of diorite rock. The names refer to a series of smooth rock channels that run down one section of the hill. The well-polished slides are a strange, incongruous sight. According to The Art of Geology, three theories have been advanced to explain the formation of the “slide”: glacial, volcanic, and structural.
Category:
Category (multi): Geological interest
Location: Peru
Coordinates: -13.506489354136033, -71.9814562379812

Description: (15th c. AD) A citadel on the northern outskirts of the city of Cusco, Peru, built by the Inca, particularly under Pachacuti and successors. They built dry stone walls constructed of huge stones. The workers carefully cut the boulders to fit them together tightly without mortar. Archeological studies of surface collections of pottery at Sacsayhuamán indicate that the earliest occupation of the hilltop dates to about 900 AD.

Category (multi): Megalithic structures, Polygonal masonry
Location: Peru
Coordinates: -13.507451192370835, -71.98022799143604

Archeological studies of surface collections of pottery at Sacsayhuamán indicate that the earliest occupation of the hilltop dates to about 900 AD.

properties.description:
Description: An Inca archaeological site in the Sacred Valley of Peru located in the Cusco Region consisting of an ancient maze. The maze, located at 3800 metres above sea level, is a huge rocky complex that resembles a big maze for its zigzagging structures. It is composed of two places, Kenko Grande, where there are: The amphitheater, the carved stone, the solar clock, the temple of the monkeys, the zigzagging canals, and the underground chamber. And Kenko Chico, which is more deteriorated, but still worth the trip. The site is one of the largest huacas (holy places) in the Cusco Region. Many huacas were based on naturally occurring rock formations. Here, it was believed to be a place where sacrifices and mummification took place.

Description: (15th c. AD) The archaeological site of Ollantaytambo was one of the most important citadels and religious centers in the Sacred Valley of the Incas. It was constructed by order of Emperor Pachacutec. It has temples, enclosures, sanctuaries, platforms, water channels and roofs made with stone blocks weighing hundreds of tons. In the 16th century, the war between the Incas and the Spaniards caused damage to the site, which served as an Inca stronghold. However, today most of its structures can still be appreciated.

Description: An archaeological site. It is the base of what was a round Incan tower, which is situated within the fortress Sacsayhuamán, Cuzco. It was used as a Temple of Inti, but became part of a complex of rectangular buildings which mostly still remain today. However, the temple and the two flanking towers were dismantled during the Spanish rule. What remains of Muyuq Marka indicates that it was "a round building with an open central court which had a fountain.The temple had triple walls, which were aligned with the zenith sunrise and the antizenith sunset. It was one of the three towers that were in the upper part of the Inca temple of Sacsayhuamán.

properties.description:
Description: Known as Aramu Muru and located on Lake Titicaca near the border with Bolivia, the flat stone is roughly 23-feet square, with a T-shaped alcove some 6 feet, 6 inches tall carved into it. What purpose the space once served is unknown, but the most likely explanation is that it was an abandoned Incan construction project. Locals are said to call the doorway the “Puerta de Hayu Marca,” or “Gate of the Gods,” and local legends apparently speak of people disappearing through the doorway as well as of strange sights, such as “tall men accompanied by glowing balls of lights walking through the doorway.”
Category: Megalithic structures
Category (multi): Megalithic structures

Description: The Paracas History Museum, in the small town of Chaco 4 hours drive south of Lima is home to a large collection of Elongated Human Skulls. The Paracas royalty, who died out mysteriously 2000 years ago have never been DNA tested, and this process is now being initiated thanks to the museum director Sr. Juan Navarro. The cultures represented, in chronological order are the Paracas, Nazca, Huari, Chincha and Inca, showing that the Paracas area hosted Native people for at least 2500 years prior to the arrival of the Spanish.

Description: The Nazca Lines are a collection of giant geoglyphs—designs or motifs etched into the ground—located in the Peruvian coastal plain about 250 miles (400 kilometers) south of Lima, Peru. Created by the ancient Nazca culture in South America, and depicting various plants, animals, and shapes, the 2,000-year-old Nazca Lines can only be fully appreciated when viewed from the air given their massive size. Despite being studied for over 80 years, the geoglyphs—which were designated a UNESCO World Heritage Site in 1994—are still a mystery to researchers.
Category: Geoglyphs
Category (multi): Geoglyphs
Location: Peru
Coordinates: -14.735042656325003, -75.10889693569894

properties.description:
Description: Dr. Maria Reiche trained as a mathematician and scientist, became famous for her life’s work as an archaeologist. She studied the Nazca Lines, a mysterious set of gigantic geoglyphs only visible from the air drawn by ancient Peruvians 1,500 years ago. Reiche and her colleague, Professor Paul Kosok, were the first European and North American scientists to study the drawings. After Reiche convinced the Peruvian Air Force to fly her above the lines, she published a theory suggesting the lines might be astronomical calendars due to how they lined up with the sun. Though this has since been disproved, their intense study exposed the significance of the site. Thanks to Reiche and Kosok’s research and writing, the Nazca Lines have been protected as a UNESCO World Heritage Site.
Category: Geoglyphs
Category (multi): Geoglyphs
Location: Peru
Coordinates: -14.68158327621296, -75.13680700162324
Source: https://www.atlasobscura.com/places/maria-reiche-museum

Description: (13th c. AD) An unimportant medieval castle. Little is known of the early era but it is believed the fortress was constructed under the reign of Afonso III of Portugal. The structure is constructed using stone masonry walls, the top of which is surrounded by a battlement. The north and south ends of the tower are accessible by doors opened by a drawbridge. The castle saw a defensive state in the Napoleonic Wars but never saw action. It has never been used since.

properties.description:
Description: (13th c. AD) The ruins of Torre de Vasconcellos. The ruins currently in existence are the remains of one of the rare palaces of Romanesque origin in the country. It is a structure of the "Domus Fortis" type, with the function of a manor house. The primitive construction consisted of a tower and a residential annex with a rectangular plan. The tower had a quadrangular plan and, in part, it retains its portal. A large door, cut in the same type of archway, which served to connect with the body of the annex building. In the ruins of this construction there is still a large door with an ogival arch.

Description: (17th c. AD) Forte do Cão (Dog Fort) is one of four forts built on the coast between Caminha and Viana do Castelo. The fort characteristics: bastioned maritime fortification, small in size and simple elevations, features a star-shaped plan in the Mannerist style, consisting of four unequal bastions. The face facing the sea is curved, while the opposite face is concave. In this one, the arms gate is torn, in a perfect arch. Inside are the service facilities, forming a corridor in the center of the square.

Description: An ancient Pre-Roman Iberian temple for Chthonic worship. Carved on the top of a natural schist spur, it is a ritual space believed to be related to the pre-Roman god Endovellicus. properties.description:
Description: (800-300 BC) An archaeological site. It is a set of ruins of a fortified village, with an extension of about 3 hectares. The inner space of the old settlement is delimited by a defensive line formed by two different walls, built in stone. At the larger points, the first wall reaches a height of 5.20 metres and a thickness of 4.20 metres. Inside the enclosure delimited by the walls, 36 circular constructions are visible, occupying the space in a relatively dense manner. Three rectangular structures were also identified, two of which are part of a set that has been interpreted as a cistern. At the top of the elevation, several sets of cave engravings can be distinguished.

properties.description:
Description: (2nd-1st c. BC) An archaeological site of the Castro culture. Important for its size, "urban" form and developed architecture. Little is known of the beginnings of the Castro occupation, as no structures from the late Bronze Age have been found here. Pottery from the early Iron Age has been found, when the settlement would already have been fortified. The majority of the ruins visible today have been dated from the second Iron Age, especially the last two centuries BC.

properties.description:
Description: (1st c. BC-1st c. AD) An ancient fortress used in the defense, and guarding of, the entrance from the Sebeș Valley to the capital of the Dacian kingdom, Sarmizegetusa Regia. The fortress is encircled by an elliptical wall. Inside there are two terraces. On the higher level terrace, at the highest point, an observatory tower existed. A tower house was positioned strategically near the main fortified gate. A second gate positioned through the Sebeș Valley was blocked sometime after 102 AD. The fort follows the architectural principles of the Dacian Fortresses of the Orăștie Mountains; the wall being the typical murus Dacicus. Outside the fortification there are three defensive ditches. During excavations from 1982-1983, Dacian sanctuary ruins were found.

Description: One of the most famous anomalous zones in Russia. It is often called the Place of Power. On the mountain, you can see a lot of things that are difficult to explain from a scientific point of view: Sami seids, stones with perfectly smooth splits, twisted trees, stairs to the sky. One of the most striking features is its balancing stone, consisting of a large boulder propped up by smaller stones.

properties.description:
Description: A forested, mountainous area where the indigenous Shor people have traditionally considered this area their home. Historically, they have been known in Russia for their iron-smelting skills, and for their practice of Shamanism. The park provides paths and access to particular land-forms of interest. These include: the Saga Waterfall, the Tsar's Gate rocks, the Moonlight cave, the Azasskoy cave, and over 60 other named caves and outcrops.

Description: (1st c. AD) A square chamber containing three stone benches that served as a triclinium for sacred feasts. Carved into a hillside to shield it from the wind, it is one of the few extant examples of nonfunerary architecture in Madain Saleh. Description: (1st c. AD) A Roman aqueduct. Description: (1st c. AD) An ancient Roman aqueduct constructed to transport water from the Proserpina reservoir 5 km from the ancient city of Mérida in Spain. It is made up of robust pillars, in which five courses of granite ashlars alternate with a course of brick. Arches at different heights link the pillars, whose core is made of opus caementicium. The linking arches are made of brick, except for the one that crosses the riverbed, which has very well worked granite voussoirs. There are still 73 pillars that have remained more or less deteriorated.

Description: (12th c. AD) A rock temple of the Buddha fashioned by King Parakramabahu I. The central feature of the temple is four rock relief statues of the Buddha, which have been carved into the face of a large granite gneiss rock. The images consist of a large seated figure, another smaller seated figure inside an artificial cavern, a standing figure, and a reclining figure. The rock has been cut almost 4.6 metres deep to create a rock face to accommodate the statues.

Description: (3rd-7th c. AD) A megalithic monument. It is a stone ship, oval in outline, with the stones at each end markedly larger than the rest. It is 67 metres long formed by 59 large boulders, weighing up to 5 tonnes each. The carbon-14 dating system for organic remains has provided seven results at the site. One indicates that the material is around 5,500 years old, whereas the remaining six indicate a date about 1,400 years ago. The latter is considered to be the most likely time for Ales Stenar to have been created. That would place its creation towards the end of the Nordic Iron Age.

Description: (11th- 19th c. AD) The ruins of a large medieval fortified palace and citadel. The citadel consists of a rectangular curtain wall enclosing an area of 230 by 150 metres. The walls were originally protected by 14 massive towers, but today only 12 remain. The citadel has gates on its northern, western and eastern flanks with curtain walls to connect the towers with each other. The current citadel dates primarily to the Ayyubid period while incorporating parts of the older Seljuq fortress. Extensive repairs in response to sieges and earthquakes were carried out in the Mamluk and Ottoman periods.

properties.description:
Description: (941 AD) An ancient Syrian fortress. It consists of a huge trench with a width of 9 metres, and a depth of up to 7 metres. The castle consists of three floors that include warehouses, defense towers, covered secret passages, water tanks and a unique royal palace. The castle wall was built of bricks in the style that was common in the days of Saladin. Above the entrance there are inscriptions in Arabic that speak of the castle, and the main arched corridor leads to the rooms on each side, so that the castle appears to extend over both sides. The castle also includes an iwan and a mosque.
Category:
Category (multi):
Location: Syria
Coordinates: 36.555375584016325, 38.261615050924526

Description: (11th c. AD) A medieval castle. Krak des Chevaliers can be classified both as a spur castle, and after the 13th-century expansion a fully developed concentric castle. The main building material used was limestone; the ashlar facing is so fine that the mortar is barely noticeable. The castle is one of the few sites where Crusader art (in the form of frescoes) has been preserved.

Description: (6th m.-12th c. BC) A neolithic Ugarit which was important enough to be fortified with a wall. Archaeologically, Ugarit is considered quintessentially Canaanite. The site is a sixty-five foot high mound and excavations have uncovered a royal palace of ninety rooms laid out around eight enclosed courtyards, and many ambitious private dwellings. Crowning the hill where the city was built were two main temples: one to Baal, and one to Dagon.

Category (multi): Megalithic structures, Megalithic stones, Temple complex, Necropolis/tombs complex

properties.description:
Description: A historical landmark and archaeological site. There are many examples of dolmens whose structures have been profoundly modified. The monuments occupy both sides of the valley and are of similar construction; rectangular in plan, following a very common technique among the Berbers, which consists of piling up loose stones between two squared stone walls. While the outer facing rises vertically, inside the courses are arranged in corbelling so as to reduce the surface to be covered by the upper slab. The square chamber is preceded by a very short vestibule. Another characteristic of the dolmens are the decoration that some have on the covering slab or on the walls; they are either discs in relief, or rosettes, and astral symbols which are found in certain haouanets.
Category:
Category (multi): Necropolis/tombs complex, Megalithic structures, Megalithic stones
Location: Tunisia
Coordinates: 35.90043705221502, 9.091386635582207
Source: https://fr.wikipedia.org/wiki/Thigibba https://journals.openedition.org/encyclopedieberbere/1651?lang=en
Images: https://upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/4/4c/Thigibba_Hammam_Zouakra_-_Arc_de_Triomphe.jpg

Description: Standing in a farmer's field in remote central Tunisia are the mysterious ruined stone walls of Kbor Klib. No one knows who built the structure or why: it has no inscriptions and few decorative elements. At 45 metres long, Kbor Klib is constructed of three platforms joined together by a wall, now only about 6 metres tall but thought to have once been much higher.

Description: (2nd c. AD) The Macedonian Tower was part of the Roman city fortifications, guarding the north-eastern corner. A clock tower was built on top of tower in 1884. This 48-metre tall tower had an octagonal plan with windows on every level. When the original wooden construction was destroyed by fire, the tower was rebuilt in 1894 from stone and brick and the clock renewed in 1926. In 1953 the tower was again partially destroyed by an earthquake.

Description: (3rd c. BC- 4th c. AD) The fourth largest Ionic temple in the world. properties.description:
Description: (7th c. BC) Known as the Evkaya Tombs, they were originally used as a place of worship for the gods, and only much later the building became a tomb. According to historians, the Evkaya Tombs were built in palagonite; an alteration product formed from the interaction of water with volcanic glass, giving it a chemical composition similar to basalt. A total of eight stone tombs can be seen carved into the rock, only three of them have preserved burial chambers. There are three different entrances to the stone tombs. On the front side, you can see small carved images of a man and a lion.
Category:
Category (multi): Necropolis/tombs complex
Location: Turkey
Coordinates: 41.37175802916775, 33.768337564417784
Source: https://www.dogadatatil.com/evkaya-tombs-rock-tomb-houses-kastamonu-turkey/

There are also the remains of the columns of two Heroa.

Description: An archaeological site. The settlement dates back to Hellenistic age but it was rebuilt and inhabited during the Roman and early Byzantine ages. It was probably abandoned during the Arab–Byzantine wars. There are many houses and seven of them are in relatively good condition. Four of them are one-storey and three of them are two-storey houses constructed of limestone. There are also, Basilicas, a Tetrapylon, Cisterns, and a partially unearthed Roman road.

Description: (12th-14th c. AD) The remains of a medieval castle. This site consists of two fortified chambers without connecting masonry walls. Description: (2nd c. BC-6th c. AD) The ruins of an ancient Roman town, founded on a small island attached to the mainland by a narrow isthmus. The site of the first settlement is almost completely buried under sand. The ruins of a bath, a cistern, a defense wall and a breakwater can be seen. The most important remains unearthed in the city are a bath whose floor is paved with mosaics and a small basilica on a circular base. On the opposite side of the highway stands a small theater and the agora.

Both sets of walls were constructed using large quantities of reused masonry.

Description: (5th c. BC-7th c. AD) A town of ancient Lycia. Extensive remains today include a stadium, a theatre, baths, walls, agora and several temples. Mostly the south parts of the wall still remain. Polygonal city walls from the Hellenistic Period formed retaining walls of the ancient theatre and show a high quality workmanship. Most of the remaining ruins in Cadianda belongs to the Roman Period. The necropolis has been plundered and partly destroyed. The tombs close to the city have a vaulted form, rarely seen in Lycia.
Category:
Category (multi): Temple complex, Polygonal masonry, Megalithic stones
Location: Turkey
Coordinates: 36.623835344587235, 29.116759499485937
Source: https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Cadyanda

properties.description:
Description: (5th c. BC-9th c. AD) The ancient city of Limyra. The acropolis where the early period structures are located, and the area within the Roman and Byzantine Age walls, are on the plain just south of it. Limyra is one of the cities with the most rock tombs in the Lycian Region. There are more than 400 tombs in the ancient city, and most of the tombs are known by name with their inscriptions written in Lycian language.

properties.description:
Description: (4th c. BC) The ruins of the ancient city of Kyaneai in Lycia, built on top of a mountainous area. Tombs in the form of sarcophagi, chamber tombs and rock tombs are located around thesite. There are Lycian inscriptions and figures with relief pictures on the tombs. At the top of the city there is a large ancient theater. The city, which bears the traces of Byzantine and Roman artifacts, is partially surrounded by walls, and there are no walls on the side, as some of it coincides with the slope of the mountain.
Category:

Location: Turkey

properties.description:
Description: (4th c. BC-4th c. AD) The ruins of an ancient Lycian settlement. This city is spread over a hill, and since the northern peak of the hill is higher, it is thought to be an acropolis. In addition, remains with stones in the Rectogonal technique which are thought to belong to the inner castle, are also encountered here. There are also inscriptions and grave monuments in the vicinity. Although these tombs are mostly in the form of sarcophagi, there are two house-type rock tombs with inscriptions in Lycian language.
Category:
Category (multi): Megalithic structures, Megalithic stones, Necropolis/tombs complex

properties.description:
Description: (6th c. BC-7th c. AD) The ruins of the ancient city of Apollonia. The city is located on a hill and has a walled acropolis at its highest elevation. In the east the acropolis seems to be double because a much older stockade is located inside the Byzantine walls. Two churches, a theater, baths with cisterns and a heroon are found on the western and northwestern side of the acropolis. Houses were built on the southwestern side. Six pillar tombs and one larger monument are found around the acropolis.
Category:
Category (multi): Temple complex, Megalithic stones, Megalithic structures
Location: Turkey
Coordinates: 36.18657346628375, 29.76417483318321
Source: https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Apollonia_(Lycia)

Description: (5th c. BC) The remains of a pre-Hellenistic, Hellenistic, Roman and Byzantine period ancient Greek city. The main sights are: the Upper Acropolis, consisting of: The Pergamon Altar, the Theatre, the Temple of Trajan, the Temple of Dionysus, the Temple of Athena, and the Library, plus other structures. The Lower Acropolis consists of: the Gymnasium, the Sanctuary of Hera, the Sanctuary of Demeter, and other structures. and at the foot of the Acropolis there is: the Sanctuary of Asclepius and the Searapin Temple.

properties.description:
Description: A 100-metre long late-Imperial Roman bridge. It was built as a two-level structure: the bottom vault spanned the brook. On top of it a row of arches connected the two hills that formed the urban area. The ground arch spanned the stream giving the bridge the appearance of a tube or a tunnel. It consists of a single 5.7 metre wide vault whose uphill mouth widens to 7 metres. The vault is made of rubble stone laid in mortar, resting on a substructure of ashlar stone blocks of varying sizes up to 1.4 metres. Originally featuring a continuous vaulting, it is collapsed today between metre 75 and 85, and again at the downhill exit.
Category:

properties.description:
Description: (6th m. BC) An archaeological site and open air museum. Archaeological evidence from the site testifies to its occupation from at least the 6th millennium BC up until the Medieval period. The earliest layers belong to the Late Chalcolithic 1-2 periods, contemporary to Early Uruk in Southern Mesopotamia and are characterized by adobe houses. The most prominent and flourishing period of the site was in the Late Chalcolithic 5 period, during which the so-called palace complex was constructed.

Description: (3rd c. AD) The remains of an ancient Greek summer capital and administrative center. On the ceremonial road to the south of it, there is the relief stele of Mithras; the Antiochos-Herakles handshake stele on the ritual platform, and the largest known Greek inscription in Anatolia in front of it. There is a tunnel starting from the place where the inscription was found, going 158 meters deep, and a similar rock corridor to the west of the inscription. On the platform on the hill is the burial temple and palace of Mithridathes Callinichos.

There is a tunnel starting from the place where the inscription was found, going 158 meters deep, and a similar rock corridor to the west of the inscription. On the platform on the hill is the burial temple and palace of Mithridathes Callinichos.

Description: (3rd c. BC) The site of an ancient Greek city that had survived through the Hellenistic, Roman, Byzantine, and Ottoman periods. The site spreads over an estimated 400 hectares; among the few structures remaining today are a ruined bath, an odeon, a theatre, a gymnasium complex and a recently uncovered stadion. The circuit of the old walls, which had a circumference of about 10 km, and were fortified with towers at regular intervals, can still be traced.

properties.description:
Description: (1600-1180 BC) A rock-relief monument which may date to the Hittite Empire period. The reliefs are carved on a cliff face on the crest of a natural hill. It depicts three deities; two large human figures with pointed hats and shoes with curled-up toes. Both carry swords in their belts. They are walking towards a less visible seated figure, possibly a goddess. The hats of the male figures have horns which are signs of divinity. The first figure has no beard but the second one does. The goddess also has a similar conical hat. The area around the goddess figure possibly had a script too, but nothing is left of it. The goddess figure is located slightly higher on the rock, and thus damaged by erosion.
Category:
Category (multi):
Location: Turkey
Coordinates: 39.5140239394549, 32.569887369964924

properties.description:
Description: The ruins of an ancient Roman city. Among the ruins that have survived, are, the temple in the Ionic style with a corner cap, the sarcophagi in the necropolis and a tomb carved into a rock. The facade of the rock tomb has a monumental appearance. The burial chamber, which consists of a single room, is reached by a staircase of 18 steps, and the top of the entrance was carved in the form of a low arch and the interior was decorated with the head of Medusa . The two sides of the belt have eagle motifs. The city also has an odeon, city walls with towers. Examples from exedra and housing remains can be seen.
Category:
Category (multi): Cave Structures, Necropolis/tombs complex, Temple complex

Description: The ruins of a large Lycian city. On site there are: several ancient temples, rock tombs including one "royal tomb", an upper and a lower acropolis, a theatre, an odeon, an agora and a church. The walls and several of the buildings are of the Cyclopean masonry, with massive gateways formed of three immense stones. The tombs and the inscriptions are in the Lycian characters, but Greek also occurs often on the same tombs. Some of these rock-tombs are adorned with fine and rich sculptures.

properties.description:
Description: (1st c. BC) The ruins of a town of ancient Lycia. Its extant remains are from the Roman Empire period, but there are some indications of an earlier city on the site. The ruins lie in a valley at the foot of a steep hill, at whose base is a stretch of Cyclopean wall containing a gate. The ruins include a number of buildings of good Roman work, among them a small Temple of the Augusti and a small columned stoa, and a theater. The inscriptions record a gymnasium and baths, but these have not been identified. Tombs are numerous, including “Gothic” sarcophagi, temple tombs and other built tombs, and some plain rock-cut chamber tombs.
Category:
Category (multi): Temple complex, Necropolis/tombs complex, Cave Structures, Megalithic stones, Megalithic structures

properties.description:
Description: (5th c. BC) The ruins of an ancient Greco-Roman city. Aspendos is known for having the best-preserved theatre of antiquity. Part of the theatre was built against the hill where the Citadel stood, while the remainder was built on vaulted arches. The high stage has supporting columns still in place. The scaenae frons or backdrop, has remained intact. Post holes for 58 masts are found in the upper level of the theatre. Also on site is a unique 19 km-long Roman aqueduct. Nearby stand the remains of a stadium, baths, basilica, agora and nymphaeum. The Roman Eurymedon Bridge, reconstructed in the 13th century, is also in the vicinity.
Category:
Category (multi): Temple complex, Megalithic structures, Megalithic stones
Location: Turkey
Coordinates: 36.939141355245596, 31.173280823388033
Source: https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Aspendos

properties.description:
Description: (1st c. AD) The remains of the ancient city of Kitanaura in Lycia. The history of the city is largely unknown. The acropolis of Kitanaura was located on a hill surrounded by the remains of other structures. Walls for the protection of the acropolis were 1.30 metres thick and have been preserved to a height of 5 to 6 metres at a few places. Remains of a basilica are found in the southwestern corner of the acropolis. Another large basilica stood in the centre. A large bath-gymnasium complex is the best remaining building, it consists of a palaestra and six other sections. The remains of a wall of huge irregular cut blocks that leads to the bath from the hill on the west side of the forest way may belong to the aqueduct. A road which runs from the south of the acropolis and then turns north, passing the acropolis to west, is flanked by necropoli on both sides. A heroon is found south of the acropolis.
Category:
Category (multi): Megalithic stones, Megalithic structures, Temple complex, Necropolis/tombs complex

Coordinates: 36.6450907736737, 30.3643464583207

Description: (3rd m. BC) The ruins of an important city in ancient Pisidia. The remains of the city consist mainly of parts of the encircling wall and of the acropolis. A few traces have survived of the gymnasium, the stoa, the stadium and the basilica. There are also the outlines of two temples, but the best conserved monument is the theater, restored in the 3rd century AD. Selge was the seat of a bishop; it remains a titular see of the Roman Catholic Church.

properties.description:
Description: (7th c. BC) The remains of a Greek and Roman city on the coast of ancient Lycia. Phaselis has three harbours: the 'Northern Harbour', the 'Battle Harbour' and the 'Protected (Sun) Harbour', of which the last is the most important today. A 24-metre-wide ancient street runs through the middle of the city. The 'Hadrian Waterway Gate' is on the southern part of the street. There are ruins of shops and stores on the sides of the street and near these are ruins of public places such as Roman baths, agoras and theatres. These structures are dated to the 2nd century BC. There are water canals between the town centre and the 70 m plateau. There are also numerous sarcophagi.
Category:
Category (multi): Temple complex, Necropolis/tombs complex
Location: Turkey
Coordinates: 36.52521381643894, 30.55301942338803

properties.description:
Description: (10th c. BC-15th c. AD) The remains of a city of ancient Caria. The main sights at the archeological site itself are: the acropolis fortified with Byzantine walls, and a smaller fortification nearby, called Heraklion, the theater with a capacity of 5,000 guests, the palaestra with its Roman baths, a wind measuring platform, a domed Byzantine basilica, the port agora, the stoa and the nymphaeum. Six temples have been excavated, two of Hellenistic and four of Roman origin. Outside the official Kaunos archeological site, there are: Six rock tombs, the Kaunos city walls and the niche tombs at the port of Çandır.
Category:
Category (multi): Temple complex, Necropolis/tombs complex
Location: Turkey

properties.description:
Description: (1000-900 BC) The ruins of an ancient Greek city. On the acropolis stand the remains of the Doric order Temple of Athena, six of the original 38 columns remain. To the northwest, two massive Hellenic columns still mark the entrance to the city. West of the acropolis stands the well preserved city wall and main gate with towers. An ancient paved road leads northeast through the gate to the ruins of a large gymnasium, an agora and a bouleuterion. Further south is a theatre built for 5,000 spectators. On the hillside are the remains of a cemetery full of broken sarcophagi.
Category:
Category (multi): Megalithic stones, Megalithic structures, Temple complex, Necropolis/tombs complex
Location: Turkey

properties.description:
Description: The remains of Çem Castle are on a high rock cliff. There is an inscription on the left side of the entrance tomb, carved into stone and quite worn. On the right side of the entrance door is a cross motif in a circle carved into a stone. At the top of the arched entrance door are two lion figures facing each other with high embossments placed in the arch walls. A window was opened at the top of the door to control the entrance of the castle. The upper structure is made of rubble stones and there is a cross motif in the circle on the left side of the window opening. On the right side of the entrance door is the figure of a lion made in the shape of a relief in the entrance direction on the outer surface of the bobbin.

Location: Turkey

properties.description:
Description: (2nd m. BC) The remains of the capital of the Hittite Empire in the late Bronze Age. At its peak, the city comprised an inner and outer portion, both surrounded by a massive and still visible course of walls. The inner city was occupied by a citadel with large administrative buildings and temples. The royal residence, was built on a high ridge now known as Büyükkale. The city displayed over 6 km of walls. To the south lay an outer city, with elaborate gateways decorated with reliefs showing warriors, lions, and sphinxes. Four temples were located here, each set around a porticoed courtyard, together with secular buildings and residential structures. Outside the walls are cemeteries.
Category:
Category (multi): Megalithic stones, Megalithic structures, Megalithic statues, Necropolis/tombs complex

Description: (2nd c. AD) The ruins of a Roman castle which was also used by the Byzantines, Arabs and the Akkoyunlus. Built on a large rocky hill, the castle was made of hard limestone. The walls and bastions surrounding the castle were made of white cut stone, and the interior was filled with rubble stone and filling materials. There are large caves under the western entrance, which is surrounded by a deep defense ditch carved from rock on four sides. There are various building remains and a water well in the castle. The castle has two arched gates in the east and west.
Category:
Category (multi): Megalithic stones, Megalithic structures
Location: Turkey
Coordinates: 37.1627504014239, 39.47115347551206

properties.description:
Description: (4th-5th c. AD) The remains of the ancient city Şuayb, a settlement dating back to the Late Roman period. It is rumored that the Prophet Shuayb used a cave here as a house and a place of worship. There is a cave in the region that is still visited as the seat of the prophet. The houses in this settlement are presumed to be the summer residences of the people living in the Harran Plain. These houses were built in the style of typical Roman houses. No comprehensive archaeological research has been carried out in the ancient city of Shuayb so far.
Category:
Category (multi): Megalithic stones, Megalithic structures
Location: Turkey
Coordinates: 36.866725768693556, 39.376765136881296

properties.description:
Description: (5th-4th c. BC) The acropolis of the ancient L:ycian city Tios. On the hilltop lay the remains of a Lycian fortress, evident by the remains of a Lycian wall and Roman-era wall. Public buildings dating from the Hellenistic period lie on the slopes of the acropolis. The sanctuary, thought to be for the local Lycian deity Trggas, stands on a platform formed by quarrying the rock on the northern slope of the acropolis next to the palace. On the slopes leading up to the acropolis are numerous Lycian sarcophagi and many house-type of rock tombs and temple-type rock tombs cut into the rock face of the hill. One such is the Tomb of Bellerophon, a large temple-type tomb with an unfinished facade of four columns featuring a relief in its porch of the legendary hero Bellerophon riding on his winged horse so called as Pegasus. A carving of a lion or leopard is inside the tomb.
Category:
Category (multi): Temple complex, Megalithic stones, Megalithic structures, Cave Structures, Necropolis/tombs complex
Location: Turkey
Coordinates: 36.5548693567542, 29.41948286756593
Source: https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Tlos
Images: https://upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/f/f8/Tlos_Stadium_4152.jpg

Description: An ancient monument which reflects the general characteristics of the Phrygian rock monuments. The monument is known as the "Tip Fountain" by the local people. It has a rock-hewn gable roof and flattened side walls. The deep niche, which further strengthens the three-dimensional appearance of the monument, symbolizes a building entrance. There is a well going down from the top of the roof to the floor.

properties.description:
Description: (7th-8th c. AD) An ancient Phrygian castle located on a rocky plateau. In the western part there are chamber tombs with monumental facades and relief decorations belonging to the Roman and Byzantine periods. The eastern part is surrounded by steep cliffs where there are several silos, a large cistern with stairs and a two-room Phrygian rock tomb with a monumental, relief-adorned entrance. The exterior of the tomb was embossed in the form of a typical Phrygian structure with a pitched roof.

Location: Turkey

properties.description:
Description: (161-180 AD ) The Antonine Fountain. The fountain was built during the reign of Roman Emperor Marcus Aurelius. It is a monumental building with a width of 28 metres and a height of 9 metres. The construction of the fountain was crafted with stones of seven different colors, and features were used and covered with Afyon marble. Numerous sculptures adorn the work, two of which belongs to Dionisos, the god of wine and theater.

properties.description:
Description: (27 BC-4th c. AD) The Inscription of Lukyanus and Equestrian Rock Relief. It consists of a 1.85-metre-long horse relief and a niche carved on a steep rock 10 metres above the ground. On the right is an inscription of ten lines, measuring 0.85 x 0.95 meters, at a height of five meters from the ground. In this inscription, horse races to be held for a cavalry who died at a young age and the rules of these races are mentioned. The monument is dated to the Roman Imperial period.

properties.description:
Description: (13th c. BC) A large statue of the Hittite Storm-God Tarhun, depicted in a mountainous temple, standing above a mountain god between two lions. The statue is 2.75 metres in width and 8 metres in height. It weighs about 70 tons and is made of basalt stone. Its current location is close to its quarry, and this suggests that the statue never made it to its final destination. Certain parts of the monument are carved in more detail and some other parts are in rough shape.

properties.description:
Description: An ancient Roman aqueduct in what was the small Greek town of Pamphilia. The aqueduct of Aspendos transported water over a distance of 19 km.The aqueduct is the usual assemblage of a buried masonry channel and an array of bridges and tunnels. Remains of several bridges and tunnels can be observed along its course. The main importance of this aqueduct, however, lies in the last 2 km of the conduct, immediately north of the acropolis hill of Aspendos. Here are the well-preserved remains of the Aspendos inverted siphon which made this aqueduct famous.
Category:
Category (multi): Megalithic stones, Megalithic structures
Location: Turkey
Coordinates: 36.944561393648335, 31.16848827921015
Source: http://www.romanaqueducts.info/aquasite/aspendos/index.html#:~:text=The%20aqueduct%20of%20Aspendos%20transported,discharge%20of%2040%20l%2Fsec.

Description: (2nd-1st c. BC) An archaeological site. The presence of a Hellenistic temple, dedicated the Hermes, and polygonal masonry implies that the site was originally a Hellenistic site. The church on site however is probably a 6th-century Byzantine building. Although the ruins are scattered around, only three building are partially standing. There is another building which was probably a tower to the south of the temple. There are also ruins of cisterns, sepulchers.

Description: (6th c. BC) A historical region that was one of the countries of the Persian Empire. The deep valleys and soaring rock formations are dotted with numerous archaeological wonders, including homes, chapels, tombs, temples, and entire subterranean cities harmoniously carved into the natural landforms. properties.description:
Description: (3rd c. BC-2nd c. AD)The remains of a relatively small city in the Lycian League. Rhodiapolis stands out as a successfully planned, very compact Roman city in limited and difficult terrain with a uniquely intricate and packed layout of buildings without leaving empty space other than the streets. On site: Two thermal baths, the palaestra, cisterns, the caldarium, tepidarium and frigidarium. The city walls, the agora, a two-story stoa and the Opramoas stoa are also important monuments. The remains of a small theatre, a temple of Asclepius, sarcophagi, and churches are still visible on the site. A Lycian cemetery complex was also discovered.
Category:
Category (multi): Megalithic stones, Megalithic structures, Temple complex, Necropolis/tombs complex
Location: Turkey
Coordinates: 36.387983101435715, 30.26608382338802
Source: https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Rhodiapolis
Images: https://upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/1/13/Rhodiapolis%2C_Lycia%2C_Turkey_%2816216306663%29.jpg

Description: (13th c. AD) A historic castle. The castle was built on the remnants of earlier Byzantine era and Roman era fortifications. After the area was pacified under the Ottoman Empire, the castle ceased to be purely defensive, and numerous villas were built inside the walls during the 19th century. The 6.5 km wall which surrounds the castle includes 140 towers. 400 different cisterns were built to serve the castle. Today the building is an open-air museum.

properties.description:
Description: (130 AD) A triumphal arch which was built in the name of the Roman Emperor Hadrian. Hadrian's Gate consists of two colonnaded facades, three entry arches rising above four pylons and a tower standing on either side. It is about 8 metres high. The upper part has three apertures in the shape of a cupola, and except for the pillars (made of granite) is built entirely of white marble. The three passage ways are decorated with floral and rosette reliefs.

properties.description:
Description: (6th c. BC) The remains of the Sanctuary of Leto. The foundations of the Hellenistic temple dedicated to Leto, and her children, Artemis and Apollo, have been excavated. Archæologists have excavated much of the ruins; discoveries include the Letoon trilingual, bearing inscriptions in Greek, Lycian and Aramaic, which has provided crucial keys in the deciphering of the Lycian language; it is conserved in the Fethiye Museum. The site remained active through the Roman period. The site was Christianised by the construction of an early church, which reused cut stone from the sanctuary, but was abandoned from the 7th century AD.
Category:
Category (multi): Megalithic stones, Megalithic structures, Temple complex
Location: Turkey

properties.description:
Description: A national park which takes its name from the mountain Güllük Dagi, which was known in prehistory as Solymus and the ancient city of Termessos. The most significant remains of the park are the ancient city walls, towers, King's Road, Hadrian's Gate, the gymnasium, the agora, the theatre, the odeon, richly decorated tombs, and cisterns with a drainage system. Other features of the Natural Park are the step rocks of Gulluk Dagi and the Mecine Canyon.

properties.description:
Description: (3rd c. AD) One of three burial mounds in central Bergama. It has a diameter of 140 metres by 26 metres high and about 80,000 cubic metres of earth was used for its rise. The tomb is unique: It is the highest open tomb in Europe with this type of pyramid structure, and it is even possible it turns out to be a worldwide unique discovery. This will become clear only after being fully exposed. Archaeologists have assumed that the building was completed in the middle of the 3rd century.

Description: (13th c. BC) The remains of an ancient Hittite Holy Water Temple. It is famous for its carved Hittite period reliefs. It measures 4 metres wide by 7 metres high. Eflatun Pınar is a distinguish example of ensuring implementation of profitable water regime through collecting water in a central system and using it in case of necessity. The monument is unique not only in its form, layout and iconography but also the technology and craftsmanship used in its construction.

properties.description:
Description: (2nd m. BC) The ruins of the ancient Anatolian city Soğmatar, otherwise known as the "City of Prophets". The ancient city attracts the attention with its historical wells, rock tombs and reliefs. It is said that Prophet Moses lived in this city. In this region there is a mound located in the middle of the village, dated to the Chalcolithic period and described as sacred, shows that Soğmatar was founded before the Common Era, and the remains of walls and bastions on the hill reveal that the mound was used as a castle for many years. The ancient city also attracts attention with its temples of the moon and sun gods.

properties.description:
Description: (16th-13th c. BC) A sanctuary of Hattusa, the capital city of the Hittite Empire. This was a holy site for the Hittites. It had two main chambers formed inside a group of rock outcrops. Access to the roofless chambers were controlled by gateway and building structures built right in front of them, however only the foundations of those structures survived today. Most impressive today are the rock reliefs of Chambers A and B portraying the gods of the Hittite pantheon.

properties.description:
Description: (3rd m. BC) The Alacahöyük Ruins where four civilizations were unearthed in excavations. Alacahöyük 1st civilization level; The Late Chalcolithic Age, that is, the first civilization founded on the main land. Alacahöyük 2nd civilization level; The Late Bronze Age; dynasty tombs were added, which contributed greatly to the enlightenment of the indigenous Hatti Civilization. Alacahöyük 3rd civilization level; Temples, the Sphink Gate and buildings were added. The temple consists of large buildings, private-block houses, streets, large and small water channels, the city wall, decorated sphinxes, one of which is embossed. The Sphinx Gate, which was built with andesite blocks on a limestone foundation, is 10 metres wide and is the monumental gateway of the great temple. Alacahöyük 4th civilization level; Represented by the Hellenistic, Roman, Byzantine, Seljuk-Ottoman periods.
Category:
Category (multi): Megalithic stones, Megalithic structures, Temple complex
Location: Turkey
Coordinates: 40.23398142976592, 34.69605427791106
Source: https://www.kulturportali.gov.tr/turkiye/corum/gezilecekyer/alacahoyuk-muze-ve-orenyeri

properties.description:
Description: (8th c. BC) An ancient Urartian fortified site. It is composed of fortification walls as well as the remains of an Urartian royal palace. There are upper and lower sections of the fortress in which the Temple of Khaldi or Irmushini, citadel walls, king's tower, workshops, storehouses, cisterns, kitchen, palace with a throne room, royal toilet, harem and colonnaded halls are located. A moat surrounded sections of the fortress. The fortress stands out by the high quality of its masonry. Aside from the cyclopean wall, the blocks used in the fortress are smoothly finished and fit exactly together without mortar being used.
Category:
Category (multi): Megalithic stones, Megalithic structures, Temple complex

properties.description:
Description: (4th c. AD) An impressive tumuli of the eastern Crimea. The Royal Kurgan is located about 5 km northeast of the town centre, close to the memorial to the defenders of the Adzhimushkay quarry. The mound is almost 20 metres high and its base perimeter is about 250 meters. It holds a burial chamber with a square floor plan, which gradually merges into the circular shape of a corbelled dome. The total height of the burial chamber is 8.84 metres. Also the dromos, a 2.80-metre-wide and 37-metre-long acute entrance passage, is built in the corbelled vault technique. Both parts of the building are made of yellowish limestone blocks and have a floor from a tamped mix of clay, lime and limestone. There are about 200 burial mounds in Kerch and its immediate surroundings.
Category:
Category (multi): Necropolis/tombs complex
Location: Ukraine
Coordinates: 45.37390875155496, 36.52611671968994
Source: https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Royal_Kurgan

Description: (3rd m. BC) The location of a Bronze Age site. Other remains include settlements, tombs, and a falaj dating from the Iron Age. Some of the site is located outside the park in a protected area. The Hili Grand Tomb is a tower measuring 12 metres in diameter that has been reconstructed. The tombs belong to the Umm al-Nar culture. There are also 3000-year-old fingerprints found at Hili II. They apparently belonged to craftsmen who constructed a wall at the site.
